151026076.review:
Resident Evil HD REMASTER is a faithful and respectful reimagining of the survival horror classic that introduced the world to the Spencer Mansion and its terrifying secrets. The game's remastered visuals, improved controls, and enhanced sound design bring a new level of polish and immersion to the experience, while preserving the core gameplay elements that made the original so beloved.

For fans of the original Resident Evil, the remaster is a must-play, offering a nostalgic journey back to the Spencer Mansion with modern visual enhancements and refined controls. For newcomers to the series, the remaster provides an excellent opportunity to experience the game's iconic environments, puzzles, and characters, albeit with some limitations due to its adherence to the original design.

I wholeheartedly recommend Resident Evil / biohazard HD REMASTER to fans of survival horror classics and those seeking a nostalgic yet enhanced gaming experience. The game's remastered visuals, refined controls, and enhanced sound design elevate the original's atmosphere and gameplay, making it a worthy addition to any gaming library.

150723281.review:
9/10

* Atmosphere and Gameplay: The game is set in the corridors of Spencer Mansion, creating a potent atmosphere. The game design sends you looking for keys and objects to solve puzzles, increasing the stakes as the chances of getting mauled or caught without the right resources increase. This constant pressure makes it a difficult game to play, but one that still manages to be fair.

* Resource Management: Since the GameCub, the game has been tense of resource management. Every zombie you spend precious ammunition to kill becomes a ticking time bomb that’ll turn into something much more deadly if you don’t dispose of them properly with fire or headshots

* Graphics and Controls: The HD remastered edition of Resident Evil looks pretty good, thanks to 1080p and some nicely touched up backgrounds and textures. You´re playing at mouse and keyboard? Well, good luck.

So...the game is gold, but let´s be honest: the voice acting is disturbing!

150524578.review: An HD Edition of the 2002 remake, of the 1996 original that started it all. This was the game series that started the Zombie Game craze that captivated fans and challenged game developers. You assume the role of either Chris Redfield former USAF, or Jill Valentine a former Delta Force operator. Both members of the "Special Tactics And Rescue Service" (STARS) Alpha Team. After answering the distress call from their comrades of Bravo Team, they encounter hellish zombie dogs that forced a handful of the surviving team to the Spencer Mansion. This is where the nightmare unfolds, and the threat of Bio-Terrorism was born along with creatures from a biohazard leak. Tank controls made it's home here, which separated the hardcore from the casual. Item and resource management are the main keys of survival. Each of the two playable characters have their individual strengths and weaknesses. Memorising map layout to help back tracking and efficient traversing of the terrifying domain. Skillful dispatch of the many monstrosities aid ammo conservation, thus improving odds of making it out in one piece. Enter the Residence, and vanquish this Evil! But make no mistake...IT WONT BE EASY!

150264649.review:
After decade, I revisit the Resident Evil remake.

Having played both the original and the GameCube remake in the past. My impression of both versions is that they differ, but both are commendable.

Initially intended as a GameCube exclusive, the 2002 remake later expanded to other platforms like the PS2. Remarkably, despite its 2002 origin, the game has aged gracefully. Even after two decades, it manages to keep up with contemporary graphic demands, securing its position as one of the best survival horror games. The controls pose no issues for me, but the occasional abrupt change in control due to map-switching can be a minor hiccup for speed runners. Aside from that, I have no complaints about the game and experience.

Regarding the story, I didn't expect much, as the focus is on introducing and exploring the origins of the RE outbreak. Emphasis is placed on game-play, replay value, suspense, and inventory management.

Differences between the original and the remake (if my memory serves me well):

Original Version:
[i]The original game features larger maps with more zones and rooms to explore. Some rooms from the original were omitted in the remake, such as the hidden room behind the glass of the greenhouse area. In the original, players had to mix various chemicals to eliminate a plant (not Plant 42). Navigating the original RE can be challenging, with the outdated map system. What I particularly enjoyed about the original was the abundance of diaries to collect and read, a feature somewhat lacking in the 2002 version.[/i]

[b]However, the strengths of the remake includes:[/b]

1. An improved and intricate map system.
2. Stunning graphics.
3. Numerous selective options.
4. Multiple endings.
5. A more in-depth exploration of the Spencer family and their discoveries.
6. Partner assistance.
7. Self-defense support.
8. Diverse enemies, including crimsons and bees.
9. A range of available bosses, such as the Elder Crimson and Lisa.

In conclusion, my Resident Evil game play provided a satisfying blend of nostalgia and enjoyment. For newcomers to the series, I highly recommend starting with the first Resident Evil game.

150088149.review:
[h1]7/10[/h1] This game is awful and I hate so many of the design decisions the devs made... and I really enjoyed it. The requirement to use a consumable resource for saving progress is honestly genius and forces you to save only when it is absolutely necessary. The game actively encourages you NOT to use ammo; killing a zombie takes like 20 pistol bullets and they respawn even stronger and faster.

To get rid of 1 zombie you need to first kill it (ammo gone) and burn it (find fuel and lighter). This makes backtracking, which there is a lot of, excruciatingly painful but forces you to carefully plan routes and burn zombies in certain areas, while saving your lighter fuel in others. You also have to git gud at evading enemies. Finding new items also means backtracking to a safe room and depositing items into the chest as you've basically no inventory space. The puzzles are solid even if a lot of the time it's basically "slot the square crank into the square hole" type stuff.

None of this is helped by the fixed camera angles and abrupt transitions when going from one part of a room to another. Some of the camera angles are right in your asshole and so you can't even see zombies come at you - and it's great, it creates tension and makes you listen for enemies and carefully survey your environment. Didn't mind the level transitions, so maybe I'm not a zoomer after all. The bosses and story aren't that interesting but the overall gameplay loop is weirdly addicting.

They just don't make games like this anymore. 

Resource management, puzzles, changing routes/environments, difficult enemies and bosses. Its a game that actually requires you to think without ever feeling like a slog. You'd think it would be with all the backtracking, but the game keeps the same areas fresh thanks to its excellent enemy design. Old enemies, if you didn't handle them well enough, come back stronger, while new enemies pop-up as time goes on. And its so satisfying revisiting old locked areas with keys and items required to progress.

The game also manages to stay legitimately scary despite having so many weapons at your disposal, both through the use of well-timed and well shot jumpscares as well as disturbing designs and lore.

The ultimate version of the first horror game. The best horror game. Buy it now.

149765118.review:
"Resident Evil HD Remaster" is a polished update of the game that established the survival horror genre in the gaming world. Here's an extensive review detailing why this game remains a must-play:

Historical Significance:
"Resident Evil HD" brings players back to the roots of the survival horror genre. It preserves the original game's groundbreaking elements while updating it for modern audiences. The game is a piece of video game history, showcasing how the genre began and how far it has come.

Graphics and Atmosphere:
The remaster significantly overhauls the graphics of the original 1996 game, with updated textures, models, and lighting effects that enhance the eerie atmosphere of the mansion. The fixed camera angles, a signature element of the original, add to the tension, often hiding dangers just out of sight. These angles, combined with the detailed environments and improved visuals, create a sense of dread and anticipation that few games can match.

Sound Design:
The sound design in "Resident Evil HD" is exceptional. Every creaking floorboard, distant moan, and ambient noise contributes to an immersive horror experience. The game's soundtrack is iconic, with haunting melodies that linger with players long after they've turned off the console.

Gameplay Mechanics:
While retaining the deliberate, tank-like controls of the original, the remaster offers an alternative control scheme that can make the experience more accessible to newcomers. The game's pacing is deliberate, forcing players to consider each action carefully, from managing limited resources to deciding when to fight or flee. Puzzle-solving remains a core aspect of the game, requiring players to pay close attention to their surroundings and think critically.

Storytelling:
The narrative of "Resident Evil HD" is classic horror. As members of the elite S.T.A.R.S. team, players unravel the mysteries of the ominous Spencer Mansion and the secrets it holds. The story is filled with twists, betrayals, and the kind of campy dialogue that has become endearing to fans over the years.

Character Choice:
Players can choose between two characters, Chris Redfield or Jill Valentine, each with unique storylines and challenges. This choice adds to the game's replay value, as each character's experience differs in inventory space, available weapons, and support from other characters.

Survival Elements:
The game's inventory management and save system (using a limited number of typewriter ribbons) are integral to the survival experience. Players must constantly make decisions about what items to carry and when to save, which adds to the game's tension and difficulty.

Replayability:
"Resident Evil HD" has high replay value due to its multiple endings, hidden items, and unlockable modes. It rewards thorough exploration and mastery of its mechanics with new challenges and content, encouraging players to revisit the mansion again and again.

Impact on the Genre:
The remaster not only stands as a testament to the original game's impact but also influences the modern survival horror games that followed. Playing "Resident Evil HD" is not just about experiencing a great game; it's about understanding the evolution of the genre.

In conclusion, "Resident Evil HD Remaster" is an essential play for both fans of the series and those who appreciate the horror genre. It skillfully balances nostalgia with modern enhancements, making it a definitive version of a classic game. Whether you're in it for the scares, the story, or the history, "Resident Evil HD" delivers an experience that has stood the test of time and remains as compelling today as it was at its inception.

149735026.review:
Some advice for new players: 

Play as Chris first or no balls.

No you don't need the lockpick, no you don't need the puzzle skips, no you don't need the grenade launcher, no you don't need Barry, no you don't need the two extra inventory slots, no you don't need the handgun immediately, and no you definitely don't need to look at Jill (remember, she's just a platonic friend). 

You don't need any of that - all of that is a distraction. Real chads play as Chris first because they know what matters: Becoming a legend. This is where the Redfield legend starts. This is where [i]your[/i] legend starts. Don't be distracted - just focus on your legend. Those multiple trips to the item box build character and will pay off in the end. Your future self will thank you when you punch your first boulder. 

Don't cheat yourself. Play as Chris first. And don't even think about picking the easiest difficulty - that isn't the Redfield way.

149563098.review:
a good game, but isn't the best initial introduction to the series for modern audiences.

i decided, for the spirit of Halloween, to get into the resident evil franchise. this was overall a fun experience, but there were times where i just needed to stop playing because it can get very linear (especially if you play as Chris)

speaking of Chris, character selection. my first experience with the game could have gone better if i knew the pros/cons of the characters (that being that Jill has more inventory slots than Chris).

the puzzle aspects were honestly pretty fun, especially examining items. and, it's very helpful that the game tells you when key items have been used out, so you don't have to constantly carry around items that you aren't sure are even useful anymore.

the forced camera perspective wasn't actually a problem for me. if anything, i kinda found it entertaining! felt like walking through frames of a comic book, in a way. but, it makes it so you cant see surrounding areas sometimes.

i have not played as Jill, and i know that her story and some of her game play will be different. even so, i won't see myself returning to this game for a little while. i will without a doubt return to do the Jill run, but it won't be for a couple months.

all in all i had a fun time playing, and will without a doubt be getting into the rest of the RE franchise. but, this game could probably go with a remake to not only be accessible to and appeal to a modern audience, but to improve on the faults.

i'm open for discussion on this. i know that my opinion will somewhat differ with others. i can sometimes get a wrong impression with some stuff, but i'm not the type of person who would choose to stay ignorant.

149541841.review:
The 89 hours I currently have in this game are from one (1) play-through, and I can't wait to play it again. It's an absolute 10/10, even if some of the puzzles feel a bit convoluted, and I'm weirdly impressed by Jill's boob jiggle physics? I absolutely recommend this to anyone who likes psychological spooks, suspense (this doesn't feel like a horror game to me, but it's definitely tense), or those Nancy Drew mystery games you had to buy on CDs to play on PC.

There's so much to see and look at, so many cool places to just run around or stand in one spot and look at all of the detail in the level and sound design (I often left Jill in the safe room and just did my homework while the theme played lol). Despite being form '02, this game is GORGEOUS and I never got tired of the atmosphere at any point in any area of the game.

I spent so much time running in circles in the Spencer Mansion, you could've told me the whole game took place in this one house (excluding the outside areas) and I'd believe you. I love how many little things you see or interact with that don't feel like they've got any significance (especially if you're used to mowing down zombie enemies in games like L4D), only to be reminded later (in some genuinely tear-jerking moments) that these were all once people, and to me, that's the creepiest part of this game. The words "itchy tasty" are enough to give me a genuine shiver when the thought pops up, especially at night. I haven't had my back to a closet door since.

There's a LOT of running back and forth, tons of puzzles, and yeah, the mansion is absolutely bonkers, but you get so many well thought out explanations through notes and lore about how and why this place is an absolute madhouse, the house itself feels like a character, and a fucking weird one at that.

149371811.review:
I thought I came to know the horror genre in gaming with Resident Evil 4 and how its atmosphere and game design evoked a foreboding sense of tension, but I realize now that was only child’s play compared to Resident Evil 1’s true feeling of claustrophobic terror. This game was fun, but more than it was fun it was spooky. So spooky, that I couldn’t play for more than 2 hours per session without needing to take in between as I’d be exhausted from the tension created from its eerie sound design that is determined to get me in cold sweat with the percussions and screeches it utilizes in scaring me . 

It is incredibly visually distinct. The use of a limited color palette is fantastic in portraying Spencer’s Mansion as this grand yet haunting area where you’ll never know what could be at the other end of the corridor. This game doesn’t have jumpscares but it really does feel like anything can pop up at any time. Considering this is a remake, I liked that they kept the door transitions despite not needing to as that added pause transition between rooms create this sense of dread as you enter a new room. 

Narratively, Resident Evil 1 is a lot less goofier than what I expected after playing Resident Evil 4 as the urgency of finding a way out of the terrifying mansion is a lot more felt compared to strolling and taking your time in saving the president’s daughter. However, the choices some of these characters make truly baffle me as it all falls into the same cliches I’ve seen over and over in horror movies. “Let’s split up” and “you go on ahead” will be common in tilting me as I just find it so convoluted that they’d want to be on their own despite being in near death scenarios multiple times. The worst part is when a certain betrayal happens but the victim never ends up asking why and what’s happening. Otherwise, the story was still pretty gripping up to the end where they use a grenade launcher to kill the big bad. The characters aren’t really much to speak about since Jill is really just a stand-in for the player and I can’t say a lot about their personalities or character traits besides me finding Jill hot, but that's okay.

Do I like the gameplay? Yes, but only to a certain extent. The fixed camera angles don’t bother me as I thought it would as I quickly got used to them and learnt to appreciate how the chosen framing can actually help a lot in setting up the creepy atmosphere. Having scarce resources also added to the overall horror experience and considering how simple it is to aim at zombies and also being unnecessary a lot of the time, things were relatively easy. Despite that, it was still overall incredibly enjoyable in solving the puzzles while navigating through the corridors of the mansion and running away from zombies. I did have a major issue with the very start though with how little it guides you in some of the mechanics like combining and examining items you get, but that's just probably old games am I right? 

Overall, Resident Evil (2002) was another great experience as part of my horror binge and is so far the most I have been scared of with a video game. Beyond some hiccups in the early parts, I thoroughly had a smooth playthrough of constantly getting exhausted from the tension and needing breaks every 2 hours or so. 8/10, the spooks are for real.

148119825.review:
[h1] Resident Evil HD: A Haunting Masterpiece Remade for PC! [/h1]

Resident Evil, originally released in 1996 and remade in 2002, is an iconic survival horror title. Its recent PC release marks the return of director Shinji Mikami to the genre he helped shape. This isn't just a piece of gaming history; it's a brilliantly designed and claustrophobic masterpiece.

I must admit, I initially expected a more realistic zombie-infested survival experience - barricading windows, collecting supplies, and dealing with infections. But that's not the path Resident Evil takes. Instead, it offers a mansion filled with abstract puzzles and campy dialogue, which at first left me somewhat disappointed. I was looking for a deep survival experience and psychological thrills, not an intricate item hunt wrapped in a Sci-Fi Channel storyline.

The moment a Resident Evil game delves into its extensive backstory, it risks losing me. I've never been particularly invested in the series' narrative, so it's the actual gameplay, scares, and set pieces that pull me back in. Fortunately, Resident Evil Remake delivers in these areas.

The main plot is relatively tight and engaging, drawing inspiration from mad scientist B-movie narratives and comic book conspiracies. The subplots, including the one added in the 2002 remake, provide intense moments of terror. But what really shines is the game's design.

While it might not be the complex simulation I expected as a teenager, Resident Evil's layout is nothing short of a masterpiece. The mansion and its surroundings form the foundation, its intricate map transitioning from black to red to green as you progress. The entire location remains claustrophobic, even as you explore its darkest corners. There's a sense of purpose in almost every scene, with even seemingly empty hallways offering some challenge.

Management is the name of the game, whether it's handling combat, rationing ammo and healing items, or planning a route from a safe room to a problem. Resident Evil is a slow-burning experience, always offering a thread to follow or a puzzle to solve. Applying the right pressure – finding the correct item or using it in the right place – allows the mansion to unfold and unravel before you.

However, not everything is perfect. The lack of direction can be frustrating, leaving you stuck or unsure of your next step. The game's first couple of hours can be particularly bewildering as multiple paths open up and then lead to dead-ends.

Even the boss fights, while requiring different strategies, essentially operate on the same principle as the puzzles. They're about bringing the right equipment to the fight, more about calculations than reflexes.

The beauty of Resident Evil is in its resource management. You'll constantly weigh the risk of going down a certain corridor, contemplating if it's worth the ammunition needed to deal with lurking zombies. As you progress, healing items become scarcer, and ammunition runs low. The save system and limited inventory space may seem irritating at first, but they're core to the design, encouraging players to plan ahead.

As for the story, it's as cheesy as ever, though thankfully without the labyrinthine mythology of the later games. It's enjoyable in the way that Roger Corman's Poe adaptations are, offering moments of fear amid the campiness. The standout is the Lisa Trevor subplot, which debuted in the Gamecube remake. It's genuinely unsettling, making it all the more shocking in contrast to the rest of the narrative.

In terms of visuals, Resident Evil Remake is impressive, although some textures look dated. The increased resolution doesn't completely remove the game's VHS-like quality, and that's a good thing. It looks beautiful but maintains its original gritty atmosphere.

While the remaster lacks some extras, I wish there was more information about the game's design and development. Nevertheless, playing Resident Evil Remake has been a revelation. It may not be as bold as it was when it first launched, but I've come to appreciate its intricate design. What might have initially disappointed me has become a delightful and intriguing experience.

This release is a chance to revisit a classic, meet Lisa Trevor, and for those who've never played Resident Evil, it's the perfect time. It's a piece of gaming history that has shaped the survival horror genre. When a game is crafted this meticulously, the shortcomings of imitations become glaringly obvious.

147951551.review:
Definitely a great game and the HD remaster looks fantastic - but it didn't just add to the look it added new content and story line that works seamlessly.

IMO this seemed to be a labor of love by the creators and is the game the way they originally envisioned it.

I'm still not a huge fan of the fixed camera or the original controls. Using Alternative controls where the joystick moves in the direction of the camera was a definite improvement. The fixed camera is suppose to add to the feeling of horror because you imagination fills in the blanks better than any graphics ever could... but this fails for me because I always know I'm looking in the "right" direction as I can't be looking anywhere else... with a moving camera (as in RE2 for example) hearing noises and trying to look in 360 degrees at once adds a great deal to the terror for me.

The one thing that I think is essential to know before you buy the game is that it is very sensitive to your controller. If either of the joysticks on your controller drift, don't fully re-center, or won't reach maximum extent - this game will punish you like you can not believe.  Even though you don't have control of the camera with the right joystick it is used to "flip 180 degrees"... if it drifts you will flip in circles... if the movement joystick has issues the difference between running and walking can be brutal - in some cases it is fatal to run and in almost every other case it is fatal to walk. I had to buy new joysticks and rebuild my controller to get through this game.

[h2] Introduction [/h2]

Resident Evil, a timeless horror franchise, has captivated gamers since its debut in 1996. This review, penned in 2023, reflects upon the enduring appeal of this iconic series and its impact on the survival horror genre. As a longtime fan, my journey through the Resident Evil universe has been one of fear, excitement, and nostalgia.

[h2] Graphics and Visuals [/h2]

[✔️] 🎮 Graphics quality and detail: Resident Evil has seen a significant evolution in graphics over the years. The latest entries showcase stunning visuals, with intricate character models and detailed environments. It's a testament to the series' commitment to pushing technical boundaries.
[✔️] 🖼️ Art style and design: The art style has remained consistent, blending elements of horror and suspense. Character and creature designs are memorable, adding to the unsettling atmosphere of the series.
[✔️] ⚙️ Performance and optimization: Resident Evil games have generally been well-optimized, ensuring smooth gameplay experiences. However, the hardware demands can vary depending on the title.

[h2] Gameplay [/h2]

[✔️] 🎮 Controls and responsiveness: Resident Evil has gone through control refinements, transitioning from tank controls to more modern schemes. The shift toward responsive controls has made recent entries more accessible while preserving the tension that defines the series.
[✔️] ⚙️ Mechanics and gameplay depth: The gameplay mechanics have evolved to include intricate systems such as resource management, puzzles, and intricate combat. These elements contribute to the immersive horror experience.
[✔️] ⏩ Pacing and balance: Resident Evil masterfully maintains a balance between moments of intense action and sheer dread. The pacing varies across titles, catering to both action-oriented players and those who seek psychological horror.

[h2] Story and Narrative [/h2]

[✔️] 📜 Engaging storytelling: The Resident Evil series is known for its complex narratives, filled with twists, conspiracies, and memorable characters. The overarching storyline, spanning multiple games, adds depth to the franchise.
[✔️] 👤 Character development: The growth and evolution of characters like Leon S. Kennedy and Claire Redfield have kept players emotionally invested. The series offers a mix of established favorites and newcomers, each contributing to the narrative.

[h2] Audio and Sound [/h2]

[✔️] 🎵 Atmospheric soundtrack: Resident Evil's music enhances the overall experience, from the haunting melodies of save rooms to the adrenaline-pumping boss battle themes. The soundtracks are masterfully composed to complement the horror.
[✔️] 🔊 Voice acting: While early entries were infamous for their voice acting, recent titles have featured impressive performances that breathe life into the characters.
[✔️] 🎼 Ambient sound: The sound design, including eerie footsteps and distant groans, creates a chilling atmosphere that immerses players in the world of survival horror.

[h2] Settings and Customization [/h2]

[✔️] ⚙️ Graphics settings: Recent Resident Evil titles offer a range of graphical options, allowing players to tailor the experience to their hardware.
[✔️] ⚙️ Gameplay settings: Customization options cater to various playstyles, with features like difficulty levels and accessibility settings.

[h2] Content and Replayability [/h2]

[✔️] 🕒 Abundant content: Resident Evil games typically feature a variety of game modes, collectibles, and unlockables that encourage replayability. The addition of downloadable content (DLC) expands the gameplay experience.
[✔️] 🌐 Modding support: While official modding support varies, the Resident Evil community has produced an array of mods, enhancing graphics, gameplay, and even introducing new stories.
[✔️] 🎖️ Achievements and challenges: Completionists can dive into challenging achievements and in-game challenges that extend the life of each title.

[h2] Multiplayer (if applicable) [/h2]

[✔️] 🌐 Active multiplayer community: Some Resident Evil titles incorporate multiplayer modes, providing cooperative or competitive experiences. These modes are well-received by fans and contribute to the games' longevity.

[h2] Bugs and Technical Issues [/h2]

[✔️] 🐞 Patched issues: Over the years, Resident Evil games have received patches to address technical issues and bugs. These updates have improved performance and stability.
[✔️] 💻 Hardware demands: The hardware requirements for Resident Evil games can vary, with recent titles demanding more powerful systems for optimal performance.

[h2] Cons and Drawbacks [/h2]

[✔️] 🚫 Cons and drawbacks: While Resident Evil has consistently delivered exceptional horror experiences, it may not appeal to those seeking fast-paced action. Some players might find the early tank controls and fixed camera angles of the original titles challenging.

[h2] Would You Recommend This Game? [/h2]

[✔️] 🤔 Would you recommend this game? Absolutely. Resident Evil remains a pinnacle of survival horror, offering an unparalleled blend of terror and storytelling. Whether you're revisiting classic entries or diving into the latest releases, there's no shortage of thrills and chills in the world of Resident Evil.

[h2] Additional Comments [/h2]

[✔️] 💬 Additional comments: As I reflect on the impact of Resident Evil in the gaming industry, I'm reminded of the countless hours spent exploring haunted mansions, confronting bioterrorism threats, and surviving zombie outbreaks. The series has a special place in the hearts of horror enthusiasts and continues to innovate while staying true to its roots.

[h2] Overall Summary [/h2]

Resident Evil, now in its third decade, remains a hallmark of survival horror. Its ability to adapt and evolve while preserving the core elements of fear and tension is a testament to its enduring legacy. Whether you're a veteran of the series or a newcomer, there's never been a better time to experience the horrors of Resident Evil.

147722457.review:
The game that laid the foundations of survival horror deserved to be remastered, and they overdelivered with one of the greatest games of all time with Resident Evil. This version is the HD version of the 2002 remaster and the gameplay is phenomenal. You are trapped inside a zombie filled mansion, but combat is difficult because of the claustrophobic setting and a tight inventory system that makes you question if you should really pick every item you find. Amazingly, the remaster goes the extra mile to bring new areas to some levels that improve on the original game.
This gameplay cycle scales really well as the game story develops. It's all about the reason of a zombie outbreak, and how main characters Chris Redfield and Jill Valentine explore the mansion, each with their own story and small gameplay tweaks. The remake tries to maintain some of the campy charm of the game its based on, to my personal delight.
Resident Evil is visually breathtaking, it was for its 2002 release and it is today with this HD remaster, using the old technique of pre-rendering its graphics to use with fixed camera angles. The result is used to enhance the game performance with improvements such as real-time reflections and a remarkable use of light sources. 
The soundtrack is very well suited for this horror game, and can even be listened on its own, but some songs in this HD version are sped up. It is still a perfect rendition of the original soundtrack. The sound design is great, since there always are scary background sounds to keep you on your toes. Monsters can be distinguished by their cries and moans, which is really cool. 
Once you beat the game, based on your performance you will unlock new gameplay modes with even harder rules, new costumes for the main characters to wear and new weapons, encouraging you to finish the game faster each time. Not much more content is offered, but the game honestly does not need it.
Overall, every element of the game elevates the horror that you will experience the first time, with a gameplay developed to scare your eyes, ears, hands and mind, and will haunt you until you finish it again, and again. The original PlayStation game was really good, but this one? Simply one of the greatests.

147645810.review:
The quintessential remake, yet to be surpassed by any other in this medium. Incredibly detailed visuals, astounding soundtrack, corny, yet well-delivered dialogue, near perfect gameplay and substantial replayability define it. Capcom set the bar so high, that no other game remake might ever top this work. It makes the original wholly superfluous, outside of pure nostalgia or curiosity. REmake is one of the best games ever made and it's king in its series for these reasons.

This port has some flaws to note. The resolution of many textures is sub par and shows that Capcom fought against their own art design when upscaling it for the HD era. The OST was sped up, but there's a mod for that as well. The faces and models were retouched, and look different from the GC ones, some more drastically than others. In general however, it's nothing that cannot be fixed with some mods. There are also some optional toggles, like original aspect ratio and modern controls, which break the game by the way, allowing one to dance around enemies freely. I must admit that I enjoy tank controls and this game was meant to be played with them, which contrary to popular belief, are not counterintuitive at all. After a couple of minutes, you'll adjust to them.

Resident Evil was, without exaggeration, a masterpiece, and while the HD version is not without caveats, it's the best way to experience REmake next to the original disc and hardware, if you can stomach such low resolutions.

It takes a while to get used to the mechanics, but otherwise, it's a fun game. The true horror of this game comes from its save system, where saving is limited and part of resource management. It makes the game more intense and forces the player to be mindful of their resource spending. Not knowing how far you are from the game's end makes it really stressful to save, with the fear of possible backtracking. Thankfully, the game provides save items plentifully, so it's not as punishing to save often. Although I'm glad it's not present in future remake games (except for re2 remake hardcore mode).

Overall, I found the game to be an enjoyable experience. I especially enjoyed my second playthrough as Jill, where it was fun to optimize routes to speedrun the game. 

Total playtime including both Chris and Jill was about 18h.

147105096.review:
[h1] The Game That Started It All [/h1]

Resident Evil has always been one of my favourite franchises, in fact I'd probably say it's my favourite overall if I had to pick one, ever since my Uncle gave me the "Claire Disc" for Resident Evil 2 for the Playstation 1 back when I was just a kid.

However that's where it started for me, Resident Evil 2, I'd never actually played Resident Evil 1. So after about 18 years of putting it off, I decided to finally give it a go after completing all of the other mainline games.

The remake is great, definitely the definitive way to play this game although there are some problems but there's a lot of fun to have here.

Firstly, the setting and sound design is great. In this Resident Evil, a Zombie feels like a genuine threat that you need to decide whether it's worth skipping round him or taking care of him. I think that's what makes this game enjoyable, it really is true survival horror, you need to decide when to use your bullets and when to know to save them.

The puzzles are good if not a bit convoluted at times, it might seem obvious when you've figured it out but there will be times when you've got absolutely 0 idea and will take a little peak online just to nudge you in the right direction. Although what I will say is that when you figure out a puzzle on your own, it feels amazing.

Combat is okay, it's a little rough and a bit tank controlly, but it is what it is, I'd say this is just a product of time and age.

Camera angles, they do take a bit of getting used to, but it's really not as bad as everyone makes it out to be, in fact I quite enjoyed it when I -wasn't- in combat. In combat it's a nightmare, but running around from place to place, it really makes the game feel movie like. I didn't mind it as much as I see other people complaining about it.

Story and dialogue is a bit cheesy, but the files are where the game shines. The spoken dialogue feels quite robotic but when you're reading through the jarring files of the whole scenario, it makes the world feel more alive. I always like it when the game feels bigger than the protagonist, that there was something going on during your mission and way before it. To me, the story's are the ones where you're just a smaller role in a bigger world who can make -some- difference but not completely resolving the problem.

Overall, Resident Evil 1 for me is a solid 6/10, it's enjoyable and possibly replayable on harder difficulties where the puzzles are apparently more difficult; camera angles are a bit of a nuisance at times and inventory management can feel like a chore. Definitely a good one and done.

146880005.review:
conocida como "Biohazard" en Japón, es una franquicia de videojuegos que ha dejado una huella indeleble en el mundo del entretenimiento. Desde su debut en 1996, la serie Resident Evil ha evolucionado y se ha diversificado en múltiples juegos, películas y otros medios, dejando una marca perdurable en la cultura pop y el género de horror.

El juego original de Resident Evil, lanzado en 1996, sentó las bases para lo que se convertiría en un género por sí mismo: el survival horror. La atmósfera opresiva, los rompecabezas ingeniosos y los sustos bien diseñados hicieron que Resident Evil fuera una experiencia aterradora y adictiva. La elección de personajes jugables, cada uno con sus propias habilidades y tramas, agregó una capa adicional de profundidad y rejugabilidad al juego.

La narrativa de Resident Evil ha evolucionado a lo largo de los años, desde el brote del virus T en la mansión de las montañas Arklay hasta la conspiración global que involucra a Umbrella Corporation y otros actores poderosos. La historia se ha extendido a través de múltiples entregas, spin-offs y películas, lo que ha permitido una exploración en profundidad del mundo infectado por el virus.

La franquicia Resident Evil ha demostrado ser capaz de adaptarse y cambiar con el tiempo. Mientras que los primeros juegos se centraron en la acción de supervivencia y el horror psicológico, las entregas posteriores han abrazado un enfoque más orientado a la acción, lo que ha atraído a un público más amplio sin perder la esencia del terror.

Los personajes icónicos de Resident Evil, como Leon S. Kennedy, Chris Redfield, Jill Valentine y Albert Wesker, se han convertido en figuras legendarias en el mundo de los videojuegos. Sus historias personales, luchas y relaciones complejas han sido un motor importante para la narrativa de la serie.

El diseño de enemigos, desde los zombis originales hasta las horribles criaturas de pesadilla como los Regeneradores, ha sido una parte integral del atractivo de Resident Evil. Los juegos han mantenido una sensación constante de peligro, incluso cuando los jugadores han estado armados hasta los dientes.

146810734.review:
Resident Evil HD Remaster is a lovingly crafted resurrection of the classic that kickstarted the survival horror genre. This remaster is more than just a fresh coat of paint; it's a testament to the enduring brilliance of the original Resident Evil. On the positive side, the game's visual overhaul is nothing short of stunning, breathing new life into the iconic Spencer Mansion and its ghastly inhabitants. The meticulous attention to detail elevates the eerie atmosphere, making every shadow and creaking floorboard feel genuinely foreboding. The gameplay retains the tension and resource management that made the original a masterpiece, creating a sense of vulnerability that is often missing in modern horror games. The iconic puzzles and memorable encounters remain as captivating as ever, and the revamped control options make it accessible to both classic fans and newcomers.

However, Resident Evil HD Remaster isn't without its minor drawbacks. The fixed camera angles, while essential to the game's original design, can sometimes lead to awkward perspectives that hinder navigation. The voice acting, though charmingly nostalgic, may come across as campy to contemporary ears. Some players might find the backtracking and puzzle-solving a tad frustrating, but these elements are fundamental to the survival horror experience.

In summary, Resident Evil HD Remaster on Steam is a hauntingly beautiful return to the roots of survival horror. Its visual enhancements, faithful gameplay, and unwavering commitment to dread-inducing atmosphere make it a must-play for fans of the genre. While it may have some quirks related to camera angles and voice acting, these are minor blemishes on an otherwise flawless reimagining of a horror classic. Whether you're reliving the nightmare or stepping into the Spencer Mansion for the first time, this remaster is a spine-tingling journey into the heart of fear, and it stands as a shining example of what survival horror should be.

I hadn't played Resident Evil 1 since the Director's Cut on the PS1, so finally getting this has brought back a lot of memories even with the extra changes from the original versions.

Have played through Chris' timeline and just started a new game as Jill. This game really ups the "Survival Horror" aspect it so gloriously created back in 1996. It's dark & finely refined extra attention to detail is mind blowing. Anyone not familiar with the 1st, 2nd or 3rd Resident Evil games (referring to the original from the 90's, not the remastered versions) will have a hard time adjusting to how this game doesn't hold your hand, once you're playing you are on your own. The added usage of defensive weapons, more pros & cons on which character you decide to play as and having to either decapitate or incinerate Zombies if you decide to drop a few, are great additions to the game.

Exploration, health & ammo management and a bit of patience are a must for this game, there's a lot of backtracking throughout the Mansion & for some that will get tedious. Thankfully, a majority of the game's puzzles don't take long to figure out & are a lot more straight forward compared to the original game's puzzles, there has been a few puzzles & things to do added that I've never seen before which kept me wondering & frustrated (why exploration is key), but after you get that "Eureka" moment you'll laugh at your mistakes or breath a sigh of relief in satisfaction. There is a lot of replay-ability. 

My only complaint is I found the control layout if using just the keyboard & mouse is pretty difficult to work with & I'm sure many will find it a lot easier using a control pad when playing this game, it makes character movement (Alternative or in it's Original setting), Aiming & Shooting a lot more smoother & just easier to manage when your thumbs are doing all the work & you can just focus on what's happening in game.

Would I recommend this? Damn right. Like the remastered Resident Evil 2 & 3 which followed this is an example or how to revisit previous projects & remake them right. No bugs, glitches or performance issues. If you're a fan of the Resident Evil franchise & still haven't bought this, it's more than worth the price it's dropped to.

146175532.review:
[h1] Brilliant formula, frustrating execution [/h1]
[b]Progress at the time of this review[/b]: 18/44 Achievements, finished one Chris playthrough; this is my first RE game
[b]Rating[/b]: 6/10
[b]Verdict[/b]: Somewhat of an acquired taste for me. The execution is so chock-full of immersion-breaking paper cuts that I was left feeling pity for the vast wasted potential of the core mechanisms. I probably would've given it a 5/10 and a thumbs-down if I weren't cautiously optimistic about playing the sequels.

[b]Positives[/b]:
[list]
    [*] Perhaps controversial, but: the camera angle and the character movement. I've taken for granted when games offer players plenty of freedom for camera control, and I've never thought about the ramifications of the camera angles being fixed. For me, this is the biggest factor behind the horror atmosphere and the game's unique charm to me.
    [*] As someone more familiar with FPS than survival horror that requires inventory management, I love the sense of scarcity of the ammunition. The combat also feels surprisingly engaging.
    [*] Related to the previous point, the placement of enemies and the map design work extremely well in conjunction to incentivize me to make strategic fight-or-flight decisions during each enemy encounter.
[/list]
[b]Negatives[/b]:
[list]
    [*] The storytelling and the characters are so forgettable and uninspiring. When I started, I was eagerly interacting with everything in the surroundings because I wanted to take in all the lore of this sinister mansion. I soon realized how bland the writing is and started avoiding unnecessary interactions to spare myself all the cringe. If you need an example, here's one I wish I could forget: when you interact with the shelf in the west side storage room, the game says something along the lines of, [spoiler] "The shelf is full of pills you've never seen. Many of them have changed colors." [/spoiler] Yeah, that's how bad the writing is.
    [*] The game sorely lacks respect for the players' time. Don't get me wrong, backtracking can be very rewarding if done right, but the way it works here frequently made me want to pull my hair out because I constantly found myself doing uneventful fetch quests or juggling items between my inventory and the item boxes, all while watching the unskippable animation of doors sloooooowly opening for the 300th time. No, Capcom, those don't impress or scare anyone anymore in 2015. (Thankfully, [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=378357950] door-skipping mods [/url] are a thing.)
    [*] Related to the previous point, I found it incredibly frustrating that I frequently could not identify on the map which room I should backtrack to. The way the rooms on maps are color coded to show the exploration progress does help, but not nearly enough for me. I would rather replace this feature with room labels on the maps (or some other variants, e.g. limited number of markers players that place on the map), so that at least I can more easily locate a room when I need to backtrack to it.
    [*] The puzzles are a mixed bag. Even the best ones are merely OK (e.g. the [spoiler] V-JOLT solution [/spoiler] puzzle), while the worst ones are convoluted wastes of time (e.g. the [spoiler] Pharmacy door code [/spoiler] puzzle).
[/list]

146095476.review:
Resident Evil is a staple to the horror genre, taking the world by storm decades ago and still needing no introduction today. I have always been vaguely interested in the series, I was a massive Silent Hill fan as a kid, and even more recently Dead By Daylight's crossovers have further piqued my interest. It was faltered a little bit when a few of my friends seemed to be pretty sour on the game,[url=https://www.twitch.tv/jacob_rewind] but after watching another friend live stream the game,[/url] I thought it looked pretty cool and decided I finally needed to give it a shot. I owed it to myself as a horror fan, and more importantly, I had to complete it before my friend did for lacklustre bragging rights. 

After about a week of playing nonstop, I've seen about everything the game has to offer. My takeaway? It's tricky. I really like a lot of what the game sets out to do. It has a lot of that awkward charm I love from early horror games, and the tone, while not really scary, captures that sense of mystery and dread that they were going for pretty well. However, just as it carries a lot of the strengths from the genesis of 3D horror gaming, it also has some of that archaic puzzle design the genre suffered from too. I never needed to resort to a guide, but there were a few frustrating moments where I was stuck wandering around like an idiot or fumbling with the really terrible inventory system. The first playthrough of this game, especially to someone less familiar with this sort of thing, will be a struggle. Along with the previously mentioned issues, enemies are very unconventional. Rather than killing them, they're intended to be narrowly avoided and memorised, until the second half where all threats are kind of a joke with the weaponry you can get your hands on. I feel like was I not aware of that before hand, a very easy game would've been a nightmare of constant deaths, "what kind of zombie game DOESN'T make you kill the zombies, right?"

Overall, I love the groundwork established here. Judging from the series' massive success, I think its safe to say that this formula will be drastically improved moving forwards, but as of right now, I respect this more as a starting point for something great, rather than a great game itself. Its a bit rough to get into, and hasn't aged the best. Had I grown up with the series, I think I'd have a lot more praise for it, but just getting into it in 2023, the nostalgia isn't there to cover up the plethora of flaws, and it just leaves me feeling lukewarm about it in the end. That being said, I'm very excited to see how the series evolves moving forwards. 6.5/10.

august fourth. 2020. the day the beirut bay faced a devastating force. lebanon had exploded. 

i remember playing this game as i was playing this game. i heard a loud explosion amd the sounds of screaming, crying, sirens, and most tragily, the muffled sobbing of my father. glass had impaled his skull. i loved my father, and he died on that day. when i was just a young girl, i was bullied relentlessly by my classmates. i cried to my father about it, so he let me skip school and go to the circus. he bought me cotton candy and popcorn and i played with the clowns and elephants. and while we were at the circus, my father payed the brave soldiers of the taliban army to completely obliterate the entire school with explosive shells and chemical weapons, killing all my bullies. my father cared about me, and he was a great man. i loved my father, and this game killed him.

i ordered this game on ebay from john resident evil, who hand delivered it to me. i couldve sworn i saw explosives in the back of his truck, but i decided i must have seen wrong. i then saw him drive directly towards the beirut port, and decided to start playing them game... i enjoyed it for a while... and then... boom... dead father, now im homeless too, and its all because of the creator of resident evil. in the remnants of lebanon... the empty savage wasteland... while i was salvaging for food to feed myself and my three retarded downie daughters to survive, i saw the silouette of john resident evil. he spoke to me, and he said, "i did this. i, the creator of resident evil, bombed lebanon, killing millions. remember this day, and remember that i am the cause. the next time we meet, only one of us will survive. farewell.". he then shot one of my three retarded downie daughters as he ran away.

fast foward twenty years. the wasteland has only grown, engulfing the entire eastern hemisphere. i have gone on many adventures, and became a completely different person. the only similarity between the me of the past and the me of today is my goal. my goal to find, and kill, john resident evil. the man who killed my father. i was scavenging through the ruins of israel for various jew foods, such as bagels, knishes, and latkes. i usually try not to eat heeb foods, but i had a craving, and we ran out of knefeh three years prior. but as i entered the supermarket, i saw him.

john resident evil.

he unsheathed his sword and began rushing towards me. i equipped my saber and parried his attacks. i swung for his head and he blocked it with his left hand, which got cut a third of the way through until my blade embedded itself in the bone of his arm. i tried to yank it out, but i was caught offguard and he stabbed me through the chest. but he missed my vitals. i took out my backup blade and stabbed him through the eye. i heard him scream, and his voice didnt sound like i expected. i  kicked the blade out of his hand, and took off his mask. the first thing i noticed was the shard of glass penetrating his temple. the second thing i noticed, is that i was looking at the face of my father.

"i can explain" he said to me "i had to do it. i had to end the world... for you..." EXPLAIN YOURSELF!!! i shouted. "when i was born, i was spoken to. spoken to by a man. he goes by many names. some call him god, others allah, some yaweh. but the name most true to his real form.. is resident evil. when he spoke to me, he said 'your purpose in life is to make a game. it will be called resident evil. worry not, i will guide you through this process.' So i did as he said. i started work. but along the way, i felt my true calling. i fell in love... and i had you... resident evil didnt like that. it got jealous. it started lashing out. "i will manifest myself in the beirut port, and turn into a big evil bear and end the entire world!! and the only way you can stop me is with the force of 20 nuclear bombs directed right into my face, and then to fake your death. so i had to do it. i had to protect you." 

he then died in my arms.

i rate this game a 7.5 popcorns out of to :-)

145997785.review:
[h1]Game's a classic, but it's also kinda lame[/h1]

It definitely has a great sense of style, but the actual game feels pretty lame.
Controls are clunky, story and characters are woefully underbaked with performances that are honestly just bad, and the puzzles don't really make the experience feel all that worthwhile.

The game also doesn't have all that much reason to replay it either, as both Chris and Jill go through near identical campaigns, with the only difference being an additional puzzle for Jill, your co-partner throughout the campaign, and the way you obtain certain weapons.

If you are going to play this game, please start with Jill.
She comes with stronger weapons, weapons that are obtained at a better pace, eight inventory slots instead of six, aswell as a lockpick for simple locks which further saves on inventory space, and for as minimal as it is her story is also better compared to Chris.
The only catch is that most of her ammo pickups are handgun ammo, so while you have stronger guns, you won't be able to use them as much as Chris, a fair price to pay if you ask me.

[h1]Overall, it's not bad, just not all that worthwhile[/h1]
As far as I'm concerned, if you're not checking this out for the novelty of playing the original RE for one reason or another, you're better off checking out other entries in this series.

A great remaster/remade with added bits & features that still hold up along with keeping a similar enough tone of dialogue in.
The sound design & soundscape is amazing. They know how to play with your fears & keep you on edge even when you pass a familiar room. Because of this I'm fine with backtracking my way around the area since it's not mindlessly boring.
 Scary subtext to lure you into a heighten state when examining things. Does a brilliant job of having every possible fear in the book of what normal humans are afraid of.

Graphics are pretty darn good for modern standards for me although the text on certain items & other areas are still hard to read,  there a wonderful mod out for this. It's called Resident Evil REupscale Project
I'm strangely fine with backtracking my way around the area since it's not mindlessly boring.

Nitpick: I wish the mouse cursor wasn't on the screen during the exploring & only on the status & menu etc seems odd they left it In.
Odd bug where Chris bugged out when eaten by plant maybe missing animation?

Tip: If you read the S.T.A.R.S manual in the file menu you can narrow down what rooms you need to go by checking your map. Works really well without needing  guides.
For mods & QOL try this thread.

145138558.review:
[h1] El Remake de un Clasico [/h1]

No se si me recuerden o me hayan visto, pero me estoy dando la tarea de reseñar los Residents Numerados y los 2 Revelations, ya hice mi reseña del 0 ahora este del 1 y luego del 2 Remake asi que, actualizados.

[h1] Breve Resumen de mi experiencia [/h1]

Este juego es una maravilla, aunque el juego sea viejo a mas no poder, no se siente para nada mal, me cague del susto varias veces aunque anteriormente habia jugado su presentacion del GameCube ya que recordemos este es un Remaster del REMAKE que sacaron para GameCube, apesar de que este juego salio unos meses antes que el 0 me parece que esos pocos meses es como 1 generacion de consola de diferencia y no hablo de los graficos hablo de jugabilidad, mecanicas, me PUT... encanta este juego, jugar el 0 y pasar al 1 es como ir al Olimpo luego de estar en la miseria absoluta.

[h1] Pros [/h1]

[b]* La rejugabilidad: [/b] El juego me lo pase con Chris en esta ocasión, la versión de GameCube me lo pase con Jill y ahora le di una checada a la campaña de Jill y NO ME JOD... La experiencia es muy diferente, es como pasarte 2 juegos diferentes (Salvando las claras distancias claramente), la campaña de Chris es mas dificil pero DE COJ... Y no es malo porque a Diferencia del 0 la dificultad aqui esta llevada muy bien y nunca me senti atacado (hablo de querer pasármelo rápido) cuando jugue con Chris me lo pase como un niño aparte otro detalle sumamente importante, dependiendo de como juegues tendras recompensas, desventajas y cambios en la historia pero el juego no es como un juego rol donde te dicen: Que haces? Le salvas o no? Nada de eso, tus acciones son las que cuentan nada te guía mas allá de lo justo y necesario.

[b]* Puzzles: [/b] Son bastantes intuitivos aquí a diferencia de el 0 (Que es cronológicamente predecesor pero realmente es sucesor hablando en tiempo de desarrollo) los puzzles tienen sus trucos, están bien hechos pero no son agobiantes mas bien son interesantes.

[b]* Apartado Artistico: [/b] El juego para ser viejito se ve super bien, digo viejito porque es un remaster y se sobreentiende que le pasaron una manita a las texturas, al audio y lo pulieron mas, te saca unos sustos terribles gracias a su camara tipo tanque y el sonido envolvente, tiembla 5 noches con Alfredo.

[b]* Jugabilidad: [/b] Aqui tenemos los cofres infinitos que hacen amena la experiencia solo guardas tus cositas ahi y si encuentras otra habitación segura pues todas las cosas aparecerán en ese cofre y viceversa, ayuda mucho a la jugabilidad te hace sentir libre y te permite planear tus rutas de manera mas amena, aparte de que la localización de los baules son GOD.

[h1] Contras [/h1]

Antes de todo, tengo que hacerle sus puntos negativos por cosas obvias pero ame este juego.

[b]* Camara tipo tanque: [/b] Seguimos con la camara malandra, aun asi en este juego le hicieron arreglos para que sea mas amena pero a veces es tedioso y hay puzzles que literal los vas a fallar porque la camara te hizo el chiste del MILENIO, pero no es tan grave ya que le hicieron unas mejoras para que sea mas disfrutable, aun asi no la termino de digerir.

[b]* Lore: [/b] El juego todo bien, pero cuando vamos a hablar de los siguientes Residents los personajes involucrados en el primero muestran inconsistencias, a que me refiero? Bueno que este juego al tener 2 campañas apartes (No funciona como el 2 ya que el 2 si hace que la historia de los 2 sea consistente) pues se hacen referencias en otro juegos de que tal personaje hizo tal cosa, pero en su campaña no lo hizo, pero en la otra campaña si, pero te mencionan un dato de la otra campaña y te quedas asi: 0_0.

[b]* Errores de traducción: [/b] Este es un error que depende como lo veas es grave, hay que entender que el juego es del 2002 y en esos tiempos agradece que estuviera en español, pero en ocasiones hay errores de traducción que hacen que te pierdas he incluso hay un puzzle donde te quedas bien loco porque esta traducido mal, gracias a Dios el juego es tan intuitivo que a veces te pasas los puzzles sin las pistas que da el personaje, pero cuando tienes que hacerlo con las pistas del personaje, tendrás que tener tu comprensión lectora al 2000%

[h1] Conclusión [/h1]

Este juego realmente lo ame terriblemente tenia mucho tiempo que no jugaba un juego que me hacia sentir así, su duración es lo justo para no hacerse cansino pero tampoco tan corto para dejarte un mal sabor de boca, la cámara tipo tanque en este juego sufrió unas mejoras terriblemente buenas que hacen que las personas que odiaban esta cámara tampoco la amen pero la digieran mas fácil, lo RECOMIENDO 100%

NT: Creo que haber jugado el 0 primero me esta haciendo sobre valorar este juego, espero equivocarme

144955743.review:
While it shows its age, RE1make is still a solid game to this day.

Its a good survival horror, they used the fixed camera angles smartly by hiding threats outside of view, making you have to be wary of danger, be prepared for ambushes, cause the monsters arent always making noise.

Every shot counts, just like old RE, ammo isnt abundant, so you gotta play smart by choosing your battles, and which is better to just run away.

Inventory is severely limited as well, with Chris only being able to carry 6 items at a time and Jill being 8, and trust me, you really feel those 2 extra slots has Jill, so you also gotta be smart about what you choose to pick up stuff and when, since you cant get rid of it without the item boxes, this was painful has Chris before i knew better. 

While mostly not a problem, the fixed camera angles can be annoying at times, mainly when you need to move quickly, since the camera can change abruptly, which changes the direction of your movement, and if you cant adept quickly, you might end up running in circles.

What really will get repetitive and annoying quickly is the doors, yeah, every time you go through a door or climb a ladder, you gotta sit through a fairly long animation for it, every SINGLE TIME, while theres a  mod to fix this, i feel the HD remaster of the game made over a decade after the original should have fixed it on its own.

After finishing the game with both characters you will unlock some extra modes, one being a considerably harder version of the game, and the other being Invisible enemies, yes its exactly what it says, good luck, you will also unlock an extra enemy called "One dangerous zombie" and you better take that name seriously, cause otherwise, you will die.

The story is... meh, i wasnt really invested on it, granted the backstory of one of the creatures was pretty disturbing and interesting, but in general, the plot was pretty boring, and at times seriously nonsensical, specially in Jill's scenario. 

Overall, its a good old game, it has good horror ambiance, puzzles are simple and aged well, but you do gotta expect that old vibe, so it might feel somewhat clunky, similar to the tank controls of RE4. 

I give it a 8/10

144948031.review:
Resident Evil HD Remaster offers something for every kind of player, as long as you remember that the antique gameplay does require some patience at times.
The title is still as compelling as it was twenty years ago and a lot of thought has gone into both keeping the old guard happy and appealing to a whole new audience. This classic title is now really impossible to miss.

Watch a snippet of gameplay here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pwSu8BjilMw

In 1996, Resident Evil was one of the first survival horror games and has set the standard for other games as well.
Consider, for example, the Silent Hill series, which had many similarities with the series.
In any case, it has established a genre and in the end Resident Evil managed to reinvent itself every time, although this was not always successful, but that aside.
Anyone who has played this game in the past will agree that Resident Evil has put a big stamp on the survival horror genre.
With the arrival of this HD Remastered version, the old gameplay mechanics have been given a new look and you can fully enjoy the game in HD.

Everything is pretty much the same as before, the camera angles, the movement options, and even the shooting has not changed, because you have 3 options: Shoot up and down and rotate a bit.
You hear a zombie shooting through its head, but aim upwards and if the zombie is far away, you only make sure that you riddle the ceiling. So a zombie must come closer.
Even the loading screens when you open a door are also present.
this remaster is packed with extras. At the start you can choose between the classic costume or the costume from RE: Revelations for both characters. You can also unlock new costumes. However, there are still some secrets in the game.
If you beat the game within 5 hours, in addition to an Achievement, you would also receive a weapon with infinite ammunition ammunition. If you complete the game within 3 hours, you will get an even stronger weapon, also with infinite ammunition

Is Resident Evil 1 scary? Yes, he sure is. Because you can't control the camera, you will often experience frightening moments, and now in HD!
The game looks great and is packed with extras to increase the replay value.

144753409.review:
Quick:

5/5

There are rarely sequels, remasters, or remakes that get the job done and get it done right.  When you want a game to give you the same feeling that the original did, but with up-to-date quality of life improvements, new and more impressive graphics, and better sound quality... you rarely get all of those things together.  Most of the time you get improved graphical fidelity, and everything else is either 'meh' or just bad.  Thankfully, Resident Evil HD Remaster is not one of those games.  This is a game where everything was done exactly as it should have been.  It's better, and it feels just like the original game does.  Never before has a walk down memory lane felt so good, while the nostalgia was the icing on the cake, and not the rickety supports holding the entire structure up.


More:

This is how a Resident Evil game should be remade... or remastered... or whatever.  When you want to revisit a game, but you want that touch of 'newness' so that you feel like you're experiencing it for the first time, you should look to games like this.  Games like Resident Evil HD Remaster should be the bar by which games redone are measured.  It's good... no... it's great.  I couldn't have asked for more.

The pre-rendered backgrounds are one of the staples of the Resident Evil series.  Well... they are if you grew up when I did, and you actually remember Resident Evil as it was in the past.  It felt like watching a scary movie just as much as it felt like you were playing a game.  Better yet, it felt like you were playing a character in a scary movie.  I guess you had to be there to really get the idea that I'm trying to convey, or perhaps you had to have played the games since then.  

When I played the Resident Evil 2 Remake, I did not feel like I was playing a Resident Evil game.  I did not give the game a good review, for various reasons, but I can totally see why people love the game.  It's not lost on me that the game can be viewed by some people as being amazing.  I get it.  I didn't like it that much, but more importantly... it did not capture the feeling of what a Resident Evil game is... at least not the way that I'm trying to convey it.  It was scary... yes.  It was gloomy... yes.  But that's not all Resident Evil is.  That's a surface level understanding of why Resident Evil was popular and why it basically laid the foundation for a specific type of survival horror game.

I don't remember disliking anything in this game.  I played through the game with both characters, and it was exactly what I expected it to be.  There were some new additions that weren't in the original... but it still felt like the original.  I wish that Resident Evil 2 Remake was made in the same style as this game.

Usually I touch on all the aspects of a game in a review.  I try to talk about the graphics, the sound design, the controls etc.  I'm just going to say that in this game, everything is great or good.  It is exactly what it needed to be.  It does the Resident Evil name proud.

144610988.review:
This is the remastered version of one of the most memorable "zombie survival" games of all time! Beautiful graphics, no game-crashing bugs, and everything is just as horrific and nightmare inducing as I remember! Go ahead, assume you're safe in another room after running from a zombie... heh heh heh.

From nostalgia and gameplay alone, this game is absolutely a must have! However, for Achievement Hunters, this game is also a goodie! Completely 100%able, no cheevo-breaking bugs... altho you will have quite a slog to get them all!

**ACHIEVEMENTS**

Ok, let me start out by saying... the achievement runs are going to SUCK. Like REALLY REALLY SUUUUCK!!!

They ARE doable, but you're going to have to beat the game at least 4 times (on successive cleared saves, each loading from the last one's save file, just to be safe)... at least one of which will need to happen in less than 3 hours.

The games (at least in my plays) are going to be Normal, Hard, Real Survivor, and Invisible.  Play as each character twice, one play through each for rescuing everybody, one each for rescuing nobody. Jill is, IMO, better to save for Real Survivor mode, bc more personal inventory.

This is going to be annoying and very difficult! My four playthroughs took a total of about 20.1 hours, recorded time. Steam says I played 30.1 total hours all total, so yeah...

THIS IS A DOABLE 100% ACHIEVEMENTS GAME! I ran into ZERO bugs that gave me a hangup! Some games tend to have bugs that make 100%ing impossible... NOT THIS ONE! Coupla days of dedicated Hunting, and you too can have a 100% Hunted game!

144604236.review:
My Review:
Resident Evil 1 holds an iconic place in gaming history, and after playing it, I'm reminded once again why this game is a true masterpiece. This title perfectly captures the essence of survival horror, blending atmospheric tension with challenging gameplay in a way that keeps you on the edge of your seat from start to finish.

The mansion setting is meticulously designed, creating an atmosphere of suspense and unease that's hard to match. Every creaking floorboard and distant moan of a zombie adds to the sense of impending doom, making exploration a heart-pounding adventure in itself. The pre-rendered backgrounds, despite their age, still manage to convey a hauntingly immersive experience that draws you deeper into the mysteries of the mansion.

The gameplay mechanics, while they might feel somewhat dated to newcomers, are integral to the game's charm. The limited inventory space and resource management add an extra layer of tension, forcing you to think strategically about every decision. Puzzles are both intriguing and satisfyingly challenging, making you feel accomplished as you piece together the clues and unlock new areas.

The character development and storyline are engaging, with a cast of memorable and diverse personalities, each with their own strengths and weaknesses. The dynamic between the characters adds an extra layer of depth to the overall experience, making you feel invested in their journey.

Resident Evil 1 is a testament to the fact that great game design and storytelling can stand the test of time. It's not just a nostalgic trip down memory lane; it's a genuinely compelling and unsettling adventure that's just as captivating today as it was when it first released.

If you're a fan of survival horror, or if you're new to the genre and want to experience its roots, Resident Evil 1 is an absolute must-play. It's a piece of gaming history that every enthusiast should have in their collection. So grab your trusty handgun, brace yourself for the unknown, and step into the nightmare that started it all.

143623120.review:
The HD remastered version of Resident Evil is a testament to the lasting impact of survival horror games. Capcoms decision to modernize this 1996 masterpiece with improved graphics and gameplay refinements has resulted in an experience that satisfies the veterans while captivating a new generation of players. 

The updated visuals breathes new life into the environment while preserving the sense of isolation and dread that defined the series, whether its the fixed camera angles that add tension by hiding dangers or the music that suddenly cuts out and gets capitalised on with a jumpscare, there is always a feeling of dread and isolation.The lighting effects create shadows and the intricate architecture of the spencer mansion shines with clarity. 

The gameplay mechanics remain true to the classic "tank controls" style which can be both nostalgic and polarizing for players accustomed to more fluid modern controls. While this choice maintains the original's authenticity, it might difficult for newcomers of the series to adjust to it, but it was definitely the right call from capcom.

The heart of Resident Evil lies in its exploration and puzzle-solving elements, something capcom seems to forget with every new release (cough cough re village). The mansion is filled with puzzles and secrets that really require you to pay attention to what you've seen.  While some puzzles remain as enigmatic as ever, others might feel a touch dated in design, potentially frustrating those who prefer more intuitive challenges. 

The survival aspect of the game, represented by the limited resources and strategic item management, remains a cornerstone of the experience. The scarcity of ammo and health items forces players to make calculated decisions. Should I waste 4 bullets killing this zombie or risk having to come back here and get bitten needing to use a health item? This element of gameplay is what genuine survival horror is about, creating tension.

Whether you're a series veteran or a newcomer seeking to explore its origins, Resident Evil HD Remaster offers an opportunity to relive or discover the origins of survival horror in all its gloomy glory.

TL;DR: Get it Play it : )

143077415.review:
An amazing classic!
The Story is pretty standard but does a great job at pushing the game forward. There's also notes and letters that give clues and lore into the ongoings of the mansion which are fun to read. The characters are likeable, while their voice acting might be a bit dated its still pretty entertaining. 
The Setting of the mansion is just so iconic and is filled with tones of areas to explore and survive through. I don't think there was a single area in the mansion i didn't enjoy. 
Visually, its impressive to look at. Performance was solid throughout my playtime and i didn't encounter any bugs or glitches. Even though this game was remastered for the gamecube, it still looks really nice and holds up. Art Direction is on point with every environment or enemy feeling as terrifying as the last. 
Sound and Audio are also just great with the the soundtrack being so iconic especially with the save room music and the audio is pretty good when it comes to enemies or weapons or even just environmental stuff such as puzzles being solved. 
In terms of Gameplay, it was really ahead of its time. I actually really like the movement and how well it accompanies the camera angles adding more tension. Puzzles are satisfying to solve as usual in the RE series. Enemies are well varied and are all a good challenge to go against. I also love how playing as either Chris or Jill can switch up how the main game is played such as Jill having more inventory slots whereas Chris can take more damage. This offers up a good bit of replay ability. 
Overall, Resident Evil 1 is just a timeless classic that invented one of the best gameplay hooks I've experience and spawned so many great titles after it.
