142698525.review:
[h1][b]77/100 ～ Great[/b][/h1]

Maybe it's because I am a fan of Resident Evil series, but it was a quite fun and nostalgic experience for me. The oldschool style of the game is so much nice that you can enjoy the sweet taste of old games from both the puzzles and the general lines of the game. The lore and story are kept quite simple, like a typical 90's game, as the game is probably not expected to develop that much in the future. I highly recommend you to play the game with Chris, if you want to get the pleasure of old games again. But if you don't want to tire yourself with inventory management, just go with Jill.

First of all, I must say that the fixed camera in the game is sometimes bad and annoying, and sometimes it can reflect the atmosphere in a good way. You die directly due to a mistake you made due to carelessness in the game and you start from the last checkpoint. Actually sometimes I think this is a good thing because you usually can't die that way in new generation games, but almost every scenario that can kill you in real life also kills you in this game, like using a gunpowder gun or just running while keeping a chemical bottle in your inventory blows you up. It's hard to see that before dying once, but I like these small details.

Your checkpoints are limited in the game. Only in rooms with typewriters, you can save the game if you have an ink in your inventory. Because of that it's so risky to save the game too often. And I think the real fun of the game is based on decision making. When you play with Chris you have 6 slots. And throughout the game, inventory and saving the game becomes your main enemy.

Old-style puzzles, small inventory, limited saves and checkpoints, getting rid of all kinds of monsters gives you a very sweet experience. I think it is very nice that the game forces you in this way because it is almost impossible to find a game like this nowadays.  What I said may be a disadvantage of the game according to some, but I think it's a very good thing, in my opinion at least. Because games nowadays don't restrict players in this way anymore. More precisely, they are afraid of making the gameplay so challenging, so they put difficult bosses to make the game harder. Because they are afraid that the players will get bored with the game when they die and start over. Now everyone has a library of hundreds of games and when they are bored, they can easily switch to another game. But when Resident Evil first came out, everyone had very few game and they had to finish the games they had in the end by trying over and over again. Once you complete it, you would feel very good. This game gives that old completion pleasure to the player. 

Of course, there are cons of the game, such as boss battles are not more difficult than any normal zombies, or the fixed camera is sometimes so annoying... There is also a bug that the character starts to spin for no reason when you focus on somewhere. But I think the reasons I mentioned above compensated for them for me a little.

142352116.review:
[h1] 𝕃𝕠𝕃 𝔸𝕟 𝕒𝕞𝕒𝕫𝕚𝕟𝕘 𝕔𝕦𝕝𝕥-𝕔𝕝𝕒𝕤𝕤𝕚𝕔, 𝕓𝕦𝕥 𝕥𝕙𝕖 𝕣𝕖𝕞𝕒𝕤𝕥𝕖𝕣 𝕚𝕤 𝕢𝕦𝕚𝕥𝕖 𝕗𝕣𝕦𝕤𝕥𝕣𝕒𝕥𝕚𝕟𝕘 𝕒𝕥 𝕥𝕚𝕞𝕖𝕤. [/h1]

Ah, Resident Evil, the OG... Who doesn't know this game? Who doesn't meme with its voice acting all the freaking time?

For all the things it does right, Resident Evil HD remaster does a few things completely wrong. Let's delve into them, one at a time.

In this remaster, you take on the role of either Chris or Jill, the two most famous STARS soldiers who were sent to investigate a crashsite, only to be forced to take refuge in none other than the famous Spencer Mansion... Now if you haven't been living under a gaming rock, you'd know what Frakenstein-like experiments go on there, and if you didn't know, you're about to find out.

The game keeps its survival horror formula from the PS1 era, although this time around it introduces an alternate way to play the game. The voice lines have been improved (although not much, they are still cringeworthy). Other things to note are the smooth transitions from room to room... and I gotta say I had quite a blast running through the mansion, ONLY THE FIRST TIME THOUGH. The game requires you to play with a guide open, or else you'd get lost in this palace full of zombies / braindead people (like Richard).

I stated that I had fun the FIRST TIME, because the inner achievement hunter in me really wanted to do a "no-saving, only knife" playthrough... but the thing is, after you beat the game ONCE, the game forces a punish-mechanic. Let me elaborate, one of your STARS friends who died then turned into a zombie. In the first playthrough, you could kill him no problems, you take his rocket launcher, you murder his mutilated white a*s and you move on... On your second playthrough, this guy chases you around and he's fully strapped with grenades, so if you dare hit him, you die... Imagine having been sitting down for two hours and I'm almost to the final boss, then this turd of a zombie comes out of nowhere and I jumpscare, shoot and die... and have to restart my run ALL OVER AGAIN. It's like, it's not enough that you now memorized ALL the zombie locations in the entire game, you'll have to play into this randomness... Couple that with the Invisible Enemy mode? Yup, it's a nightmare... You'd probably argue that I could lower the difficulty level; I tried... This relentless bastardo is still there, anywhere and everywhere... Gaaaah

Anyways, the game gets [b]8/10 [/b], and it loses TWO WHOLE POINTS because of Agent Forrest... Dude just won't die and rest in pieces like everybody else.

142293359.review:
Pretty great game, obviously a must-play horror title because of how iconic it is. Game hasn't aged perfectly, many of the older mechanics really show their rust (saves, opening doors, camera), but most of it can be forgiven just because the atmosphere is great. The layout of the mansion is honestly genius, having you retrace your steps and finding a harder enemy where you killed an easy one or figuring out a new part of a puzzle is a great gameplay loop that doesn't overstay its welcome. The game is concise, not too short and those clunky mechanics that slow down the game (especially repeating large chunks of the game on hard after you die) don't slow it down enough to feel like a slog.

I will say, this is my first real "horror" game I've played so far, since I've always been a big baby and too scared to ever try them. If you're like me and unsure if you can handle it, I can assure you that the horror elements of this game are really no big deal. There was never a time in the game I was "scared", more just unsettled. The game isn't a screamer and most of the scary elements come from the environment and atmosphere. I seriously suggest giving it a try, I think anyone worried about not enjoying just because they don't like horror will be surprised in a good way.

142173207.review:
It pains me in a way to have to leave a thumbs down here, but I offer a warning that other potential players coming from a similar place that I was when I tried playing this should hear. I am not at all saying that this is a bad game, obviously the vast majority of folks enjoy it based on reviews; but Steam is asking if I recommend this game, and the answer to that is definitely no. I find it hard to fathom that I would be completely alone in my reasons for not liking this, so I offer this review as more of a caveat than trying to outright say you shouldn't buy it (TL;DR at bottom).

First, I totally understand what an important game this is. The action horror genre is alive and well today, and this 27 year old game is an enormous reason for that. There's not a lot of games that have ever spawned an entire gaming category, let alone a series of movies, comics, and probably other media as well. Despite all this, I hadn't actually played any of the games. RE7 and Village look really good and I'm gonna get around to playing them, but I'm the kind of player that likes to play through entire series. So, I figured that the one that started it all is worth taking a look at.

This, of course, is not that game exactly. It's a remake. My best guess is that the parts that were re-done are done quite well. It looks nice, that's for sure. Not modern graphics exactly, but not 1996 graphics either. The control scheme/core mechanics of the game are though, and that made this totally unplayable for me. I have 3 specific major gripes which add up to being a total deal-breaker, and they're things I imagine would be major turn-offs for some others wanting to jump into this series here as well. They are the following:

[b]1: Limited Saves.[/b] Saving is tied to a consumable item that you come across in the mansion. Since bag space is extremely limited, it's enormously cumbersome that your ability to save the damn game takes up a chunk of it. These items are only usable in specific locations as well. I get that saving this way is a design choice and a mechanic that some probably enjoy about this game. Elements of it persist on through the series, but it's not something I like at all in a game like this. It's something I do like in some games too; it feels great to finally get to that next bonfire and feel safe for a second. In this game though, I found it extremely frustrating that chunks of time and progress were just totally lost because I couldn't get back to the typewriter after having to backtrack because I couldn't pick up something else I needed because of that f!(#^ng ink ribbon in my inventory.

[b]2: Fixed Cameras.[/b] Again, this is a design choice and one that works sometimes. It makes total sense in a game like this that devs want you to see it from the angles they choose. It adds tension and atmosphere and surprise and is something that's actually done well in that respect, but I found having to navigate this way extremely frustrating as well. If you keep holding the button through a camera transition you'll keep moving in the same direction. As soon as you make any kind of adjustment after the transition, you'll begin to move relative to the new camera position. Even in the calmest of moments, I found myself accidentally turning the wrong direction over and over again, even some times when I knew the transition was coming. Having this issue when attempting to run for my life was something I found completely untenable.

[b]3: Combat.[/b] I found the aiming system totally unwieldy. The fact that you can't move while aiming alone feels totally wrong to me. Once your gun is up you can only turn left and right (camera relative, of course) at enemies that may be moving around you or even off-screen. There's very little in the way of feedback as to if your shots are even hitting the target sometimes, plus ammo is of course very limited. Add in the fact that you can only get hit 3 times before you die (and you better hope you used one of your precious save items recently if you do!) and it makes combat a terrifying experience for all the wrong reasons.

There's probably some very strong arguments for why these things shouldn't be deal-breakers. There's some workarounds for some of them too, probably. I only tried one of the control options and I'm sure I could have improved at both the combat and navigation if I played more (truthfully though, I figured that with the trouble I was having with early enemies that I couldn't possibly be able to get through any fights with any real complexity later). I got to this point where I [i]had[/i] to get by this one cerberus dog. I had full health and enough ammo to kill it, but it just kept getting me over and over and it just felt like whether or not I could kill it was more of a crap shoot than anything resembling skill. It took 5 attempts before I finally managed to get it down, and I managed to die before I could get to a save point so none of it mattered anyway. It was at this point that while Steam will say I played for 2.3 hours, I had only actually made like 25 minutes of game progress and had 0 minutes of fun in the process.

Let me reiterate that all this is wholly a personal matter for me. The things I've described are all things I can get over in some games but really made trying to play this impossible. I like playing retro games and especially love the nostalgia blast of playing one from my youth. This game does not scratch that particular itch for me though, and as such I had no desire to slog through some archaic design as I have with some other games. If you happen to be somebody like me though and want to finally give Resident Evil a try starting at the beginning, heed my warning and skip this one. Do what I did: watch a story synopsis for this one and move on to the RE2 remake, it's superb. I've gotten considerably more than twice as much time into that one now, have loved every minute, and can still feel like I did my due diligence to the series.

So in conclusion I suppose: the odds are, if you're gonna buy this game you probably will like it. Even in the frustration I was experiencing, the elements of what made this series persist are clearly there. They were buried under what I personally found to be some unplayable systems that anyone looking to replay a game they once loved (or possibly anyone simply with more patience than me) could probably get over. This concludes my warning, thanks for sticking with me this long.

TL;DR: A masterpiece from 1996 that spawned an entire genre, but unfortunately still plays like a game from 1996. Skip it and start playing the series at the RE2 remake.

141198262.review:
Resident Evil is a classic survival horror game that defined the genre and spawned a successful franchise. The game follows the members of a special forces team who are trapped in a mansion infested with zombies and other horrific creatures. The player must explore the mansion, solve puzzles, find weapons and ammo, and fight for their survival.

The game was originally released in 1996 for the PlayStation, but it was later ported to the PC in 1997. The PC version features the uncensored American version of the game, which has more gore and violence than the Japanese version. The PC version also has improved graphics and sound, but it suffers from some compatibility issues with modern computers.

In 2015, Capcom released a remastered HD version of the game for various platforms, including PC. The remastered version has enhanced visuals, audio, and controls, as well as new modes and features. The remastered version is widely praised as one of the best remakes of a classic game ever made.

Resident Evil is a must-play game for fans of horror and survival games. It has a gripping story, atmospheric environments, memorable characters, and tense gameplay. It is also a challenging game that requires strategy and resource management. The game has multiple endings and scenarios depending on the player’s choices and actions.

I would rate Resident Evil 1 on PC as 4.5 out of 5 stars. It is a masterpiece of horror gaming that still holds up well today. However, I would recommend playing the remastered HD version over the original PC version, as it offers a smoother and more immersive experience. You can buy the remastered HD version on Steam for $4.99 until July 13.

Pros:

A faithful and enhanced remake of a classic game that preserves the original gameplay and atmosphere

A stunning and realistic visual upgrade that makes the game look like a modern title

A crisp and clear sound design that enhances the horror and immersion

A new control scheme that allows the player to move in the direction they want to go

A new widescreen mode that expands the field of view and adjusts the camera accordingly

A new mode called Wesker Mode that lets the player play as the famous villain of all games Albert Wesker

Cons:

The game still has some of the flaws and limitations of the original game, such as limited save points and inventory space

The game still has some cheesy voice acting and dialogue that may detract from the immersion

The game may be too difficult or frustrating for some players who are not used to the survival horror genre

141173524.review:
Most remakes tend to miss the mark completely, or just change a game entirely for the sake of changing it. This remake... It's the textbook definition of what a true REMAKE is supposed to be; it keeps the core environment of the original in-tact while changing it up drastically to fit a new era. You see this game nowadays and think "WOW, this game looks amazing!" but at one point, it was on the Gamecube as an exclusive title and it looked just as incredible back then, too!

This is how remakes are supposed to be done. You can definitely argue about the RE2make, and most definitely the RE3make, but RE1make's such a clean and honest-to-god faithful update of a once relatively... NOT-so-perfect first start to the franchise we now all know and love. It even threw in references to the just... LEGENDARY dubbing of the original on PS1. This is such a loving recreation of a classic, and that therefore makes it unique compared to all the other REmakes out there.

140951006.review:
When you first start the game: uWu stay away from me spooky zombie man!
When you finish the game: You are weak creatures and Imma flex on you!

You start out in a spooky mansion and die to some spooky zombies at first. Then as you progress you turn into a tactical problem solver. I can move here, I want to control this area, I need to avoid this area. Then you grasp the game is trying to spook you, but you are faster, more agile and have a shotgun. You have no reason to be afraid. Fear leaves you and you can calmly think tactically. 

The game gets easy. 

You realize the game was always easy. You were just making it harder.

This game is about puzzle solving and basic resource management. Both get much easier as time goes by. I personally don’t like having my saves limited but it does add to the stressful atmosphere at first. You must learn to manage your ammo which can be somewhat stressful at times, but I never felt like I didn’t have enough. The map tells you what you have completed and what needs to be completed so eventually you will find your way.

I have only one real complaint playing as Chris. There is this big plant boss called Pant 42 or something. When you get to the area you get these clues and unlock this room where you will presume you can make some kind of super weed killer. But you can’t make it because too stupid, I guess. I probably spent at least an hour running around trying to figure out what I was doing wrong when there was nothing I could do.

The story is mid. I think for the time it was probably pretty good. However, there are a few nice surprise moments.

The characters are, well let’s just say I don’t think you play this game for the characters. I couldn’t tell you anything about Chris or any of the other characters, except Rebeca is a medic that plays the piano. There is basically no reason to care about any of the characters, and it doesn’t feel like any of them have more than a thin veil of backstory.

The voice acting is basically a joke. It would be better to use a text to speech program for the game dialog. There may be more expression to the dialog that way. Or I guess just make it all text. Either way I just felt the dialog was cringe.

The graphics are mid. It is a remaster, but there is no 4k display option. Honestly the remaster could use a remaster. But it does give off some retro vibes.

But yeah, I like the game. You should play the game.

140760659.review: Resident Evil (1996) will now and forever be one of my favorite games of all time, back in the day this game gave people nightmares, jump scared people, even challenged some who weren't familiar with the control scheme which is commonly referred too as "Tank Controls". Nowadays it is looked back on by most people as a laughing stock, (the acting in it didn't help too much for that reason) Honestly i know to this day i still crack jokes over it's voice acting and mock how scary it used to be, despite that it still remains one of my favorites. Fast Forward to 2002, GameCube gets the Resident Evil Remake, one of the greatest survival horror titles of all time (Still to this day) There are some games that have done either just as good or a better job doing Survival Horror, Such as Amnesia and Outlast to name just a few that have done a good job. But how they remade this game was so damn amazing, New Rooms to explore, The addition of Crimson Heads making every single zombie you drop having the chance to get back up unless you burn their corpses with the very limited amount of Kerosene that you can find, making almost every room and hallway tighten your sphincter harder than sitting on an ice cold toilet seat, and not to mention the changes of where they put enemies being some of the scarier moments, walking through that infamous hallway where two dogs leap through the windows, only this time, one just shatters a little bit, it's only later something will finally come out to attack you. Adding so much to a game made in 1996, which could be beaten in just a few hours now adding at least 6-8 hours on a first play-through possibly more if you suck balls at puzzles and fighting/dodging enemies. This series has become so close to my heart that I even am going back to replay every single Resident Evil game I can get my hands on just because it's awesome, not every game is a smash hit, and some of them even are bad, at least two of them are almost unplayable (*COUGH* Umbrella Corps, *COUGH* RE-sistance) but even with all that. It's always exciting to see what is around the corner with CAPCOM and the future of Resident Evil.

140656068.review:
A thoroughly enjoyable experience. The fixed camera angles help enhance the horror, though at the detriment of character movement if you're playing with the alternate controls (the default setting). Supposedly, this isn't an issue when playing with the original controls (toggle-able in the settings), but I spent my entire playtime using the alternate controls and turned out just fine, so it's just a matter of getting used to it.

A few things to note when playing this game:

1. The initial difficulty selection menu consists of the choices "mountain climbing", "hiking", & "walking". This is equivalent to Normal, Easy, and Very Easy respectively. Hard, Real Survival and Invisible Enemy modes are unlocked later.

2. The choice between playing as Chris Redfield or Jill Valentine is an important one as they both play differently. In general, Chris is slightly more difficult to play compared to Jill, so most people recommend playing as her for a first playthrough. That being said, my first playthrough was Chris on Easy and it was fine.

3. For achievements that require multiple playthroughs ("We're in This Together", "Starsenal", "Passion for Fashion"), I believe that you need to complete them in the same save slot. When saving, remember to Overwrite as Cleared Data.

4. After completing the game with both Chris & Jill on Normal difficulty or higher in a single save slot, One Dangerous Zombie mode is unlocked. This change is permanent and irreversible on that save slot unless you delete the save itself, so plan repeated playthroughs properly if you do not wish to experience this mode every single other time you do so.

Lastly, whenever you enter a different room, an unskippable cutscene of the door opening plays. I was fine with it since it helps me compose myself, especially when trying for the speedrun achievements, but some might find it annoying, so just a heads-up to those who care.

139890669.review:
This remaster of a remake has aged surprisingly well. It shows that prerendered graphics can absolutely work for modern games.

Background: The first REmake from 2002 was my introduction to the Resident Evil franchise. I logged a whole butt-ton of hours into the Gamecube version back in the day. Did a quick run after I bought this to see if I still got it, got sub 3 hours first try. 👍

Non-spoiler tips for anyone new to these games: 
[list]
[*]Even though the camera switching may be jarring, don't let that intimidate you. If using a controller, the tank controls on the D-pad are your friend, as odd as that sounds. Hold forward on your d-pad and don't let go until you need to turn or you reach your destination. 

[*]Running past enemies *is* an option.  It took me a bit to get used to not killing every enemy in sight, but it's a crucial skill for survival horror (and Soulsborne games, but that's not what this review is for). Experiment with your controls and.

[*]Read any files you come across. You'll get hints, answers, and some chilling lore that wasn't in the 1998 RE for PSX/Saturn.
[/list]
My only complaint is a nitpick related to nostalgia more than how good this game is. [spoiler] I don't like that they patched out the infinite grenade round glitch. That glitch saved me when I was new and was great for casual runs with no unlocked weapons. [/spoiler]

All in all- It's a great remake of possibly the most influential game in the survival horror genre, given a fresh coat of paint to show it's still got it. It stays faithful to the game it was based on, while expanding on it in a meaningful way. If you want a Certified Classic™, look no further. It stands tall among the greats of its era.

[And if you feel like it when you're done with this, check out the original 1998 version. It's awful in so many wonderful ways and great where it counts. A casual eminder that jank can be a feature. And like movies, you can be bad and fun at the same time.]

139858752.review:
I remember loving RE2 back in the day, but never played RE1.
To be honest, it's too stiff. The characters are easily overwhelmed by anythings to come up in their way. The weapons are really useless and they'll never stop any of the enemies to come up to you and grab you. Not even the gun. Shoot 11 times a zombie to kill him (having to stop and move back because they don't stop coming) is quite annoying. You tell me "that's the fun of the game", but it's all trained military and police characters that can't hit a head at 1 meter distance. Ridiculous.
The fixed camera doesn't work too well with the new movement, which moves the character in the direction you press your stick, but on the camera change, the direction moves the character back instead of forward, it's really annoying in some points. The old style "tank" movement system is waaay too slow, you can't really play that way.
The character's storage is so minimal that you can easily get stuck, I had to restart the game because I picked up some shells and couldn't pick up an item to carry on. That's really bad design (having to restart a game because the character won't drop an item? really?), also unrealistic.
But back to what made me quit, is the stiffness of the characters and how defenceless they are. I got killed in the balcony after calling the dog, absolutely destroyed me, no chance of anything even having a gun and lots of bullets. 
I don't know if I'll be coming back to it, it's really boring and stupid. 
On the positive side, the camera angles is an aspect that I always liked of the first RE, they feel very cinematic, and this remastered version looks pretty cool after all these years.
It's a very flawed game in terms of mechanics, it's unnecessarily frustrating and gives the player very little option to defend against the enemies. 
Was cheap enough to keep it in my library instead of refunding it, but I'm not too sure I want to play it anyway..

The first hour of REmake is overwhelming and not fun - it takes ages to find the first item box, and before then you've already been to several rooms, seen several puzzles, and had to leave behind several items. After that it gets better, so if you're at this point thinking if you should rely on a walkthrough, I'd say give it some more time. And when it gets good, it gets really good; the flow of exploration easily tops the original, and ranks among the best in the series. 139516868.review:
The remake of the original iconic title that became a runaway success back in the PSX days, thus becoming a hit on the Nintendo GameCube. It's a game that improves on the original on most things, yet it surprisingly does away with some things that were really cool on the original.

The visuals and the iconic Spencer mansion layout received quite the overhaul, so returning vets from the PSX version had a lot of new surprises to face. The acting was much more improved over the campy, B movie style of the original (I don't really know whether to consider this an improvement or not, since the goofy voicework and corny script of the original were indeed half the fun!) The soundtrack was a remixed version of the original game and not the one used on the third version released (Resident Evil Director's Cut: Dual Shock Edition), I would have preffered Capcom had used both soundtracks and gave the chance to choose which one you would preffer on any given playthrough..., too bad.

Content wise, the game featured a new and intriguing side plot to the original game's storyline in the form of one of the new bosses you face: Lisa Trevor. Aside from that, as well as some rather surprising changes regarding Richard Aiken, the game's story doesn't really deviate much from the original. However, I do have to point the fact that the game's story now encourages a set route and order to do things, unlike the original where if you wanted to mix things up and go to places you hadn't gone earlier in previous playthroughs, you would discover additional cutscenes that changed slightly the game's story. However, new mechanics are available such as the defensive items which can save you in a pinch!

All in all, the game's pros are more numerous than its cons and I love to play this often along with the original. Just do not expect an easy challenge, for that is what defined the original survival horror genre back in the day!

139432361.review:
Resident Evil HD Remake: Zombie-Slaying Timelessness... with a Side of Crispy Graphics
Ah, Resident Evil, the game that taught us all the valuable life skills of surviving a zombie apocalypse. And now, it's back in all its HD-remastered glory! Get ready to revisit the Spencer Mansion, where the undead roams, puzzles abound, and the ink ribbons are as scarce as a decent haircut during a quarantine. This game is like a fine wine—it stands the test of time, leaving you equal parts terrified and tickled.
First things first, let's talk about those crispy HD graphics. Gone are the days of pixelated zombies that looked more like angry Tetris blocks. Now, you can behold the zombies in all their decomposing glory, with every festering wound and hungry groan lovingly rendered in high definition. It's like a terrifying art gallery where you get to shoot the exhibits. Who said the violence can't be beautiful?
But fear not, fellow zombie slayers, for this remake remains faithful to the classic Resident Evil experience. The tank controls are back, reminding us of the joyous struggle of maneuvering our characters like drunken ballerinas. You'll find yourself running face-first into walls, attempting a simple 180-degree turn, and accidentally firing your shotgun at the wall while a zombie chews on your neck. Ah, good times!
Of course, we must remember the iconic dialogue. The voice acting in Resident Evil HD Remake is a true masterclass in unintentional comedy. Each line is delivered with such dramatic flair that it's hard to keep a straight face. Who can forget the iconic "You were almost a Jill sandwich" line? It's a gourmet feast of cringe that keeps on giving.
Now, let's talk puzzles. Oh, those glorious, brain-teasing puzzles that will make you question your own sanity. Resident Evil HD Remake brings back the joy of finding obscure keys, deciphering cryptic symbols, and rearranging statues like you're trying to win a demented game of interior design. Remember, when in doubt, examine everything, combine everything, and pray that you don't run out of ink ribbons right before a boss fight.
One of the joys of this game is the sense of dread it instills. Every door you open, every shadow you glimpse, and every distant groan sends a shiver down your spine. The atmosphere is thick with tension, and the jump scares are as effective as ever. You'll find yourself nervously inching forward, holding your breath, and then promptly screaming like a banshee when a zombie bursts through the window. It's cardio and a gaming experience all in one!
Resident Evil HD Remake is a testament to the fact that a game can stand the test of time. It captures the essence of the original while adding a fresh coat of HD paint. Whether you're a long-time fan reliving the terror or a newcomer experiencing the game for the first time, there's something undeniably special about the survival horror masterpiece that is Resident Evil.
So, grab your herbs, load your trusty shotgun, and prepare to embark on a journey through the Spencer Mansion that will leave you both frightened and entertained. Resident Evil HD Remake proves that even in the world of zombies and cheesy dialogue, there's a timeless charm that continues to captivate gamers of all generations. Now, go forth and make those zombies wish they had stayed buried!

139326173.review:
Detrás de estos diálogos demenciales, esas miradas perdidas en momentos trascendentales y múltiples incoherencias se esconde un videojuego que terminó de popularizar el género que tenía a los Alone in the Dark como referencias. A veces te podrás preguntar si los agentes especiales son también zombies y no lo saben, de lo tontos que parecen, pero incluso a pesar de ellos y sus extraños diálogos, el juego no deja de resultarme súper inmersivo y la mansión un lugar en el que uno sigue perdiéndose incluso después de 20 horas recorriéndola: ¿qué pasillo desemboca en la cocina? ¿Dónde estaba el balcón que llevaba al jardín? La ambientación consigue que me olvide de cualquier otra cosa que no sea averiguar cómo salir de allí, a ser posible acompañado. Pero todo el rato me acuerdo de Edward Carnby y la mansión del Alone, incluso siendo ésta la segunda vez (veinte años después, eso sí) que juego Resident Evil.

Ya entrando en detalles, a la hora de mirarle al bocadillo lo que tiene dentro uno a estas alturas tiene la sensación de que escaseaba un poco en chorizo. Había mucho pan, riquísimo, pero luego te encuentras con alguno de los "malos" en las escenas finales y se te queda la cara a cuadros. Ahora, a 25 años vista, se ha ido cerrando el círculo de la historia, pero inicialmente tras jugarlo te quedabas un poco a dos velas con todo el tema Umbrella, el virus y demás castañas. También hay que admitir que, honrosamente, en la historia no te metían gazapos que harían sonrojar a cualquiera que haya estudiado un poco de biología, lo cual ya es mucho decir en el mundo de expertos en el que vivimos.

Al final he de presumir de que salvé a Jill y Rebecca, que es más de lo que muchos han hecho. Aunque ellas ni se han dado cuenta, sobre todo Rebecca, que siguen con esa mirada perdida como si fuesen robots. O el propio Chris, que no se ha enterado de mucho, salvo de que había un virus y tenían que destruirlo todo, como en las buenas películas de acción!

138604393.review: Once you get passed the jank this really is a fantastic game. Trust me just stick with it until you get used to the controls. It's rare I play a game 2x in a row even if it's short like this but this game made it worth it. Second play through is a blast because you know where everything is and you can basically speed run it it's also slightly different from a story prospective if you choose a different character or make different choices within the campaign. It has that classic resident evil gameplay that's just so satisfying. It's more about path finding and puzzle solving than shooting everything in sight or at least you are heavily encourage not to due to limited resources. Resource management is extremely important as well as limited with only 6 slots with Chris and 8 with Jill you are constantly encouraged to use your brain in these types of survival horror games everything is a choice. The story is simple but good the voice acting is bad but I think that's intentional due to the original having bad voice acting to be authentic. The graphics are phenomenal for it's age pre rendered backgrounds just hold up incredibly well to me because they could push much higher fidelity with it than actual 3d models at the time. The locked camera angles really add to the atmosphere of the game as well as the tension. I really don't get the hate when it comes to locked cameras I think it's extremely under rated people just need to give games more of a chance outside of the usual behind the shoulder or first person view it works incredibly well to increase the presentation.  This is currently the best way to play this game because it has actual full analog support it plays great with a controller and good on the keyboard. One thing I'll say is you should definitely play Jill's campaign first if you are a one play through type of guy because I think it's more cannon and way better then Chris's campaign which felt really anti climactic. If you love survival horror give this one a shot it's basically the Mother of survival horror.

138505769.review:
Despite showing it's age now, the REmake is still a very good way to dip your toes into Resident Evil if you're a newcomer or if you just want to see where it all began. 

Yes, the camera angles and tank controls take some getting used to, and the gameplay gets gimmicky once you learn the layouts and enemy positions, but compared to the other RE games it has unrivalled atmosphere and immersion that will keep your hairs straight, plus the art style and design of the pre-rendered backgrounds is terrific. It doesn't throw hordes of enemies at you either, even the zombies are scary and feel like an actual threat. On top of all this, it has high replay value with quite a few hidden unlockables and costumes to acquire, and it's a very speedrun-friendly game (you can easily cut down a run from 10 hours to just 2).

This Resi comes from a time when developers still put love and care into their games, and it certainly shows.

138149828.review:
I've actually struggled with myself on whether I should give it a thumbs up or down. The game is not terrible but it also hasn't aged very well in various aspects. Let me go through the core aspects of the game and what I see as positives and negatives.

[u] Graphics [/u]
The game overall in this HD version still looks pretty good. The backgrounds are well drawn and the lightning flashing in the background gives it a pretty good atmosphere. The character models are also still pretty good. Still sometimes you also find some pretty low resolution background where it will be difficult to identify things. The CGI video sequences are okay in terms of quality.

[u] Sound Design [/u]
The sound design is pretty good. You can hear your own steps on the different undergrounds pretty well as well as recognize enemies based on their sounds which is pretty important due to the fixed camera positions. The music also provides a decent atmosphere and the game also knows when to tone down the music to build up anticipation. The voice actors are doing an okay job. It's better than the original but still overall just mediocre.

[u] Map Design [/u]
The basic layout in many aspects is similar compared to the original but adds some new areas and modifies some existing ones. The remake has changed some of the older puzzles and introduced new ones. The remake is overall a bit bigger than the original I'd say and the new areas are well implemented into the overall design. Nothing feels out of place.

[u] Enemy Design [/u]
We have the classical enemies from the original and some new ones as well. In addition they've added some new mini bosses. The enemy design overall is fair. It's intended to provide a challenge while at times you have to consider whether fighting is the correct choice or running the better alternative.

[u] Story and Characters [/u]
The story and characters outside some minor tweaks have mostly stay the same compared to the original. It's a campy and goofy story about a zombie plague outbreak with some conspiracy in the background. They added some new information to build a connection to Resident Evil 2 and added some background story on the new minor bosses. It's servicable but shouldn't be taken to serious. This unfortunately affects the horror factor of the game in a negative way as you cannot really take any of it serious.

[u] Gameplay [/u]
Here comes the big issue for me as the gameplay of Resident Evil 1 has aged poorly in various aspects. Compared to the original it is now possible to use knifes and grenades to push enemies away from you and possibly land a one hit kill. In addition zombie corpses will not just disappear but if the head is still intact they will just drop to the ground and may re-awaken later. You can burn the corpses though to block that. It may be a good option in areas where you have to walk through several times. This is necessary as during your first playthrough players will be backtracking constantly and EXTENSIVELY. If you do not know where everything is located and where items have to be used you will walk/run around a LOT. Over 60% of the game is basically just running through areas of the mansion where you may to do something you couldn't do ealier or getting items into the storage room for later use as well as then taking items later again. This will be necessary as Chris for example has only 6 item slots in his inventory. If you carry a weapon + ammo you already lose 2 slots. If you add another more powerful weapon then half of the slots are already gone. Now add maybe a health recovery item and it leaves only two slots. Often you have to carry a key that leaves one slot to pick up new items. This is just poor design and a restriction to artificially stretch out the game length. Inventory management and memorizing the map layout become essential parts of the game. You really have to keep the inventory load to a minimum to ensure you can get as many relevant items as possible from your target locations.

The constant running around with backtracking where not much actually happens also causes the RE to become boring after a while. After the initial excitement and basic layout exploration the game basically comes down to:
1. Lighten inventory in storage room
2. Go to next room you haven't explored
3. Pick up relevant items
4. If inventory is not full go to next room you can open and pick up items
5. Return to storage room to lighten inventory
6. Repeat

Once you find riddles and specific key locations you will then take relevant items with you to unlock the next mystery but then it basically returns to the principle from before. Something that really annoyed me was while I was playing with the controller the stick by default always made my character run. At some point I had to pick up an item that would kill my character randomly if I started to run. So I purposely had to completely change the way I controlled the character as the standard controls would kill my character. I have no idea why anyone thought this was a good idea...

Anyway the combat controls are pretty straight forward. You go into a room and look at the door again. You hold the aim key and see if your character turns around to focus on a target. If he does an enemy is there and you can decide on whether to shoot at him or not. you can point guns up or downwards but outside of potenially knocking an enemy to the ground or blasting its head immediately when they are close it doesn't do much. The game aims at the enemies automatically and there is no skill involved there. So pretty basic combat.

The game got me a few times on jump scares (zombie behind a corner for example) but outside of that it's not really scary to be honest. Maybe I've just numbed down to much in the last few years to horror but for me the experience overall was mild.

Finally I think it's fine to buy the game when it's on sale but I wouldn't buy it at a price higher than 10€.

Resident Evil HD is an amazing experience and I can't recommend it enough! The atmosphere, pacing, writing, puzzles and combat make for one of the most entertaining games I've played. It also has a strong post-game with many modes, endings and difficulties.

Despite it's age, it holds up incredibly well. However there are a couple of notes that may challenge some:
-The default controls are not recommended, and research into better controller layouts (not re-bindable) is needed.
-Camera angles are fixed and the movement between 'shots' is a bit jarring at first but you get used to it
-Some resources are limited, including the ability to save - which has a learning curve on how to manage your resources
-A couple of puzzles are pretty confusing to solve - There was only 1 I encountered that I struggled with, the rest could be solved with trial-and-error
-The game doesn't make it clear about discardable items (keys), and it's consequences for not selecting 'yes' by not allowing you to ever get rid of it.

Overall this is one of the best games I've played and will remember it.

Don't get me wrong, this game was awesome. Did a 14 part let's play series on it for my YouTube channel and had a lot of fun.

The whole universe its creating is dope, and it is interesting to see where the franchise started. The introduction of these weird hybrid creatures, colossal bosses, hell hounds and sprinting zombies was epic, and the whole map where the game takes place is amazing where you have to go back and forth between old and new places to reveal new places in these old place.

The game also looks gorgeous! Other than the weird disconnected of the characters from their background, the environments look stellar, and the lighting in them even better.

And I really loved the feature of finding out how the game mechanics work just by playing the game, picking up books and documents, but also trial and error (bear in mind this cause some frustration on my end as well though).

But MY. FUCKING. GOD! This game frustrated me beyond measure!

The fixed camera angles, in theory, is cool. And it makes for some cinematic game-play at every turn. But fucking NO! Never fucking again. They introduced the worst gaming experience for me to date. I would sometimes spend a solid five attempts in some areas where the camera angles would change three times in a second, leaving me to have my character spinning in circles on the spot as I couldn't comprehend which button to press to just go forward. As well as this, the amount of time I died or became hurt to enemies because of these fucked fixed camera angles simply because I was rushing and didn't have time to think about every keystroke I was pressing to just run in one single direction was astounding.

The doors... fuck... the doors. I understand that this was more than likely a way to keep computers or consoles back in the day from burning up in flames from having to load a whole map. But when remastered/remade you'd expect gaming devices back then to be able to handle loading a map of this size? No? If not, then in 2023, how have the devs not done a simple re-release to remove this fucking stupid ass feature of waiting too go through doors. Ya'll know how hard it is to commentate while literally a door is opening and closing on screen?!

The puzzles nearly had my brain exploding in my head. Am I the only one that struggled with them?! Am I just THAT dumb?! I respect that almost every one of them are different and require a unique perspective of out the box thinking to solve them and this is more similar to puzzles you'd face in a real life scenario. But no. I play games to get away from real life. I need a coherent line of puzzles that aren't all out of the box and don't sometimes rely on outside components of the puzzle room and other times components inside the room and other times require you to pull objects apart or combine other components that don't even seem like they'd combine even if Jesus tried to combine them. Fuck. 

The enemies are cool, the boss battles were actually pretty easy. But the amount of times I was astounded by being killed with an INSTANT KILL when I was full health was astounding. As well as this, whoever made those hallways only wide enough to accommodate one and a half peoples should be slapped silly. The amount of times I tried evading zombies only to be running into their arms made me angry beyond belief. And the fucking fixed camera angle didn't help either.

So if you're thinking of playing this game, please do, it was a great experience, but just beware that you will get royally pissed over and over and over while enjoying the beginning of the Resident Evil-verse

137972420.review:
When I originally learned of the Resident Evil series many years ago through Resident Evil 4, I was always hesitant to go back and play the first three games due to their fixed camera & (more importantly) the long door animations. After the release of the Resident Evil 2 remake I was interested in comparing and contrasting it to it's original PS1 version from 1998. I ended up loving the fixed camera and the door animations didn't bother me as much as I expected. 

That was a few years ago; cut to present day and I decided to try out the remake of the very first Resident Evil game. While most modern gamers™ may be trepidatious to try out a game like REHD Remaster, I had heard over and over from old school fans how this is the definitive classic RE game. So I went in with high expectations, fully embracing the fixed camera (that I had grown to adore) and hesitantly accepting the punishingly long door animations. 

[h1] THE GOOD [/h1]

[b] STORY/CHARACTERS [/b]
Going in I had no expectations for this game's story beyond knowing the basic plot. However I quickly fell in love with the different characters the game had to offer. The game perfectly balances having the player feel lonely as they explore the mansion while simultaneously having recurring appearances from the cast. As the game goes on you run into the different characters, and while each interaction is short, it's expertly written to endear you to each character enough to that you genuinely care to see their story through and achieve the "best ending".

[b] REPLAYABILITY [/b]
During my hunt for 100% of achievements, I probably went through the entire game from start to finish about 6 or 7 times. Each playthrough was radically different than the previous one, due to the game masterfully increasing the challenge with each run. Modes like "Complete the game with only your knife" or "Invisible enemy mode" are gimmicky and seemingly present an unfair challenge, however the moment to moment gameplay during these modes is fun throughout, and never is there a challenge or fight that is truly insurmountable.

 The most satisfying mode by far is "Real Survival" which presents a challenge so hard I didn't dare even try it till my final playthrough. In this mode the game is set to the hardest difficulty, item boxes are disconnected (this is a huge change from the regular difficulties & modes) and auto aim is turned off. Completing this mode was truly hellish, however the satisfaction felt from seeing the credits at the end made the 37 hours~ I had put into the game to get up to that moment made it all worth it. 

[b] GAMEPLAY [/b]
The fixed camera in this game is masterfully placed, making you feel like you're watching a film throughout. There are 1 or 2 angles that most players (including myself) struggle to orient themselves around, however for the most part the angles are great. 

There isn't much variety in the weaponry, however the weapons that are available feel very satisfying to use. Especially the grenade launcher which is hilariously overpowered for a game like this. 

Boss fights are all great. 

The puzzles are all satisfying and challenging, though sometimes they can be a bit slow. 

[h1] THE BAD [/h1]

- Door animations are too long (can be fixed with mods)
- Some cutscenes are very low quality due to not being remade
- Some puzzles/boss fights have unskippable cutscenes 


[h1] CONCLUSION [/h1]

REHD Remaster is a great and satisfying game with plenty of variety to offer anyone who's willing to give it a chance. Highly recommended.

137914934.review:
All the Resident Evil games are different. Through all the years this franchise existed the developers tried new formats. But this game is closer to the PS1 retro era. Except for the controls. You can use a more convenient control scheme. This makes game easier to dive into for newcomers.

Nowadays, there are remakes of parts 2-4 with modern 3rd person camera so you may not like being unable to control the camera and properly aim. This is ok. As for me, I like that style. The camera takes spectacular angles picked by the developers themselves to present you a certain scene in the best way possible. Combined with the absence of the interface while controlling the character and thorougly drawn static lighting on the levels, that brings to the atmosphere and gives you a cinematic feeling, like you're really watching a good horror movie. Even though this camera was used just because of pre-rendered backgrounds, it made the game better and unique.

And yeah, this game is really scary. Not only because of some jumscares. I advise you to play it blind and figure it out totally on your own. That's the most proper way to play it. The first playthrough will be the most thrilling. You never know what events will be triggered by your actions. You never know if the next room will have enemies or not. And your ability to save is restricted. This makes you feel uncomfortable and paranoid. You have to manage your resources and take risks. That's why the developers called this game a survival horror. I believe games should give you emotions. Resident Evil I definitely delivers you strong ones.

The puzzles here are harder than in the subsequent games of the series. They test your memory, intuition and logic. And yeah, you have to be really observant and attentive to solve some of them. You need to search in every nook and cranny and read some important notes to figure out what to do.

I noticed that people who like Dark Souls play Resident Evil games as well. These series have a couple of things in common. Strong enemies that you have to avoid, even stronger bosses, metroidvania style of level design with searching for keys, backtracking and opening shortcuts. I could say that Dark Souls is just Resident Evil with swords and armor. But the most important feature these two share is the feeling of great accomplishment, whether it comes from taking down a strong enemy, figuring out a complicated puzzle or questline or discovering a powerful weapon in a hidden location. The main trait of that aprroach to game desgin is uniqueness of each such event. You see, every dungeon in TES or Diablo, every outpost in Far Cry or Assassin's Creed, every quest in World of Warcraft is not much different from another one. These games are repetitive. With each accomplishment, they don't give the feeling that you really reached or achieved something. Your every action is just a tiny drop in the ocean. They don't have enough value to make impress you with what you just did. Whereas in DS and RE, each action is meaningful, you feel each one of them affecting your laythrough a lot.

Of course this game is not perfect. There are some frustrating moments. For example, the camera is good for the horror, but not for the combat. Sometimes you won't even clearly see the enemy you're shooting at. Thank the character automaticallu turns to the enemy. But it doesn't work good if there are several enemies attacking you.

Some puzzles are hard to solve because you didn't find a clue because you didn't notice somewhere on the level just because it didn't stand out much and blended into the backgorund. Also there is a moment when you have to remember a note you've read a 1/3 of the overall game time ago to proceed to a new area. Some items and notes are hard to take or read for the same reason. Some of them are hard to reach because of the controls and hitboxes even if you know their locations and stand right in front of them.

Your inventory is small and there is no way to extend it. This leads to a lot of backtracking, especially when you play the game for the first time and don't know what stuff you need to take to pass certain area and what stuff you will find there. Chris has even less backpack slots than Jill so put him away for a second playthrough.

For the conclusion, I would like to state that this game deserves a playthrough, and even more than a single one. But only if you don't mind its format. It's awesome, but it's not for everyone.

137810443.review:
If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.


Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

137794534.review:
[h1] Favorite Game of All Time [/h1]
Resident Evil Remake is not only one of the best Resident Evil games, but one of the best games of all time!  It has an excellent atmosphere, satisfying game play, and great exploration.  You play as either Jill or Chris and experience their night in the Spencer Mansion.  Each character's journey is masterfully designed with many story and game play changes.  The Spencer Mansion is one of the best locations ever developed in a video game.  It is not only scary, but well designed with plenty of doors and areas that unlock as you play.  Its level design encourages not only exploration, but memorization of enemies locations and room layouts .  This is also the first game in the story, and doesn't have the issue of being unbelievable like future games.  The characters introduced are iconic and very likable. 
The issues a player may face with this game are small, but present.  The tank controls may push some people away because they function very differently from modern control schemes.  Also, as this game is over twenty years old, you will notice some places where it shows its age.  Some of the backgrounds can look a little blurry, especially in the aqua ring and a few of the cutscenes are compressed.  These issues are minor though, and the game has aged very well.
Overall, this game deserves its place as a classic.  It is the gold standard, not only for survival horror but horror in general.
TLDR  An all time great game with excellent atmosphere, gameplay and characters.  Some may take issues with controls or backgrounds, but these are minor and shouldn't stop you from play this excellent game.

137761977.review:
I've played a lot of survival horror games, and this one is by far the best. 

Many people seem to say that nostalgia is why this game is so well-regarded; however I can say I played it for the first time in 2023 and I'm still seriously impressed with how great it is. I don't find any mechanics or controls to be outdated, maybe the lack of automatic box sorting is the one exception. The optional tank controls will feel strange at first if you're not used to them, however it only takes a few minutes to adjust, and I do recommend them. They work much better with the fixed camera angles.

The initial difficulty levels as presented are 

1. Normal (mountain)
2. Easy (hike)
3. Very Easy (walk)

I'd recommend sticking with normal, although easy isn't a bad choice either as this game is more challenging than modern games. I'd avoid very easy as this will trivialize the experience. I also recommend choosing Jill Valentine as your character for the first run - she has a larger inventory and a lock pick. Chris Redfield can take more damage and has a lighter, but Jill's benefits are much stronger.

I'd rank this as tied for best entry in the series along with RE4 remake. This is the best of the survival horror RE games, RE4R is the best of the action entries.

I hope that Capcom will consider making some more survival horror entries in the mainline series, they're truly something special.

137760264.review:
this is probably my favorite resident evil. resident evil 4 may have been what breathed new life into survival horror, but resident evil 1 is what defined it in the first place. 

the spencer mansion in the arklay mountains has to be one of my favorite locations for any piece of horror media at this point. it is brimming with attention to detail, and features such a moody and oppressive atmosphere. this is in no due part to the unfathomly excellent level design. the mansion itself is like a puzzle to solve. it is beautifully interconnected but slightly obtuse on purpose, as to let the player feel like they are solving the puzzle. 

the gameplay loop is so amazing because of how much the game takes away from you. you barely get any inventory space in this game, nor do you have any idea when you are going to need any item. therefore, good item management is a gameplay element itself when going through the mansion. you have to make decisions on whether you will need to sacrifice space for ammo for a key item, or maybe you take the bigger shotgun instead of some healing items. ultimately, the game breeds player ingenuity out of restricting you. 

this game , i think is scary or at the very least...,, its stressful (the fun kind). there are a few clear reasons for this that all connect. first one, is that enemies take forever to die. couple this with the fact that you barely receive ammo, this makes every enemy a threat on the simple premise that you might not want to use ammo on that enemy since you might need it later (mayybe for a boss, for example). secondly, you back track A LOT. which means if yyou dont kill those enemies, you will be running from them forever. this makes it kind of tense to go around the mansion. you might be forced to backtrack to an area full of enemies multiple times, but you cant afford to waste precious ammo. lastlyy, you do not get unlimited save. saving is also someting you need to think about which is insanely scary. as a whole, you could technically sum up the game as a puzzle exploration game where the puzzle is item management.

the story is absurdly campy and cheesy, due to the time period it released in. like the voice acting is so silly and funny i love it. jill valentine is also soooooo good , like jill, girlllll why are you there. whyy does everyone always wanna split up around you SSKSKSKS SKSKSK .

ALSO THOSE VISUALS!!! THIS WAS A GAMECUBE GAME!!!! ?? wowwowow. like its so pretty, the art direction is spot on, it looks like scaryyness >_< and that save room theme ughhhh sooo good.


love this game <33333

137613468.review:
This game reminds me of an escape room. Often there's things you won't understand the significance of, or just won't have the key for, and you're meant to chain the puzzles together into a series of gameplay strings taking you on winding paths across the mansion and its grounds. The puzzles have some interesting logic to them sometimes, and the new horrors crawling through the area make you treat the map like a secondary puzzle, asking if you can safely make it between two places in these winding halls without expending your ever more limited supply of ammunition. While my first run on (what turned out to be) easy difficulty had me never outright run out of ammunition, I did come alarmingly close.

A side note on the difficulty selection, I did appreciate that it just asked how you like your games in terms of difficulty and focus on narrative or gameplay, similarly to how some games call their easiest difficulty a "story mode". It presented me with three options, I chose the middle one and the game accepted with no remark. No shame in choosing that way to play, just how you want to experience a game that's held up incredibly well (as long as you don't mind tank controls, but even then there's an option to use a different control scheme). Add into that a graphical upgrade that helps the atmosphere far more than any visual on the Gamecube could, and you have a remarkable piece of history brought forward for modern gamers to experience. Anyone that's a fan of the remakes would do well to experience this first remake of the franchise too.

137587424.review:
(spoilers) 

For a game that is 20 years old, it is very very good. The level design of the mansion is brilliant and the residency/aqua ring is by far my favourite area. The puzzles as a whole are really good and the game did end up scaring me a few times. 
I played on the normal difficulty and the amount of resources and saves the game gave you felt perfect. (i also so far have only beat the game using Jill) 
The game has a really interesting story and i loved the designs of the enemies especially lisa and plant 42 
The hunters were really fun to but this was because the magnum was an awesome weapon. 
This is a personal thing but i absolutely love the look of old 3d games. The games graphics in my opinion are amazing  
i love the fact that there is a very limited amount of saves. It makes each one feel precious and you have to have a little debate with yourself about if you want to use an ink ribbon or save it for later 

The weapons feel good 
especially the magnum 


There are a few issues though 
the movement feels really clunky and because of the way cameras work often times you are shooting at enemies you do not even see
This can be frustrating because as a result of you not knowing where enemies are, you can take some really cheap hits plus multiple times the cameras would change as i was running already and it would fuck up my movement which again resulted in hits that didn't feel fair.
I didn't like using kerosine to light dead zombies bodies. Often times i found myself trying to but the game just wouldnt allow me (although this could be me doing something wrong) 
I really did not like that laboratory section of the game. I thought the puzzles were good but the fuel carrying puzzle was terrible and Wesker being a villain was really really obvious.

I had a big issue with the characters. Often times things happen for plot convenience and characters sort of disappear and re appear sometimes *cough cough* Barry 

the final boss fight was cool but the whole fight is a bit underwhelming 
you sort of just shoot it until it falls over or at the very end your friend comes to save you 


Also the performance of this game is terrible 
constantly the game would drop to 30 fps and play really really slowly
this on top of the game crashing sometimes when i tabbed out was really really frustrating. 

overall even though this game isnt amazing 
its very very good and in my opinion still stands up today as a solid horror game 
my opinion on it however is that i utterly love it and think its amazing 

i would 100% recommend

I've had to resort to using an online guide 3 times because I was stuck just to realize there was actually a door I could go through that's hidden at the far corner of a room that you can't see from the camera angle unless you walk to it. Others complain about the inventory management, I don't think it's too bad, like I wish weapon slots were separate from other items but it's not the end of the world. It really is the camera angle thing that makes this unplayable.

It's such a shame, because it's actually a pretty tense and scary game.

137320928.review:
Residente del mal uno.

[h1]Lo mejor:[/h1] 

- Se trata de una remasterización del remake de Resident Evil que se hizo para GameCube en el 2002. La historia empieza en 1998, cerca de Raccoon City donde un equipo de S.T.A.R.S deberá investigar la desaparición de otro equipo ocurrido en las montañas Arklay. Hay Tensión, terror y suspenso!!
- En el juego podemos ir con Chris Redfield o Jill Valentine. Lo único que varía son las habilidades de los personajes y algunas escenas y encuentros.
- Respecto a las habilidades, por ejemplo: Jill tiene más espacio en el inventario y puede abrir algunas cerraduras sin necesidad de buscar llaves como Chris, mientras que Chris tiene más resistencia y el cuchillo que lleva es mucho mejor.
- Aparecen los clásicos zombies, perros mutados, los molestos hunters y más! Si a los zombies no les reventamos la cabeza o no los quemamos una vez que estén en el piso, más tarde se levantarán y se convertirán en unos zombies mas letales! :D
- No podemos poner un objeto en el piso como ocurría en el Resident Evil Zero, en vez de eso, las cosas ahora las podemos guardar en baúles que encontraremos por los escenarios. Estos baúles comparten el contenido que guardemos.
- Tiene gráficos mejorados y hay un buen detalle en los escenarios y efectos de luz y sombras. El sonido es impecable y algunos sonidos son escalofriantes.
- El guardado es a través de máquinas de escribir y si jugamos en la dificultad hardcore si o si vamos a depender de las cintas de tinta para poder guardar el progreso.
- Chris y Jill pueden equiparse con otras skins de trajes. Algunos se desbloquean pasando el juego una o incluso dos veces en una determinada dificultad.
- Se puede desbloquear una pistola especial si pasamos el juego en menos de cinco horas o el lanzacohetes infinito si lo pasamos antes de las tres horas!
- Al terminar el juego podemos jugar el modo supervivencia donde los baúles ya no comparten cosas.
- Dependiendo de las decisiones que tomemos habrá diferentes finales.
- Tiene jefes únicos.

[h1]Lo peor:[/h1] 

- Porque Chris tiene menos espacio en el inventario que Jill? Es muy chico el inventario que tiene y a veces se hace incómodo tener que dejar cosas por otras. Encima, como las cosas no se pueden poner en el piso hay que ir a algún baúl para hacer espacio si necesitas un objeto de misión y tenes el inventario lleno.
- No hay ningún ítem especial que te haga expandir el inventario de los personajes. Ni hablar de Chris.
- Algunos ángulos de cámara son incómodos ya que no podemos ver al bicho que nos ataca.
- Es ilógico que una escopeta y una llave te ocupen el mismo tamaño de casilla.

The Gamecube Resident Evil port from 2002 on pc is great. Thanks to the visual tricks used this game still looks incredibly good two decades later. The fixed camera angles fit the claustrophobic feel of RE perfectly and always make you feel on edge because you never know what lurks behind the corner. But such a design choice isn't without its consequences. Even though the game has a cinematic and almost realistic feel, the so called "tank" controls always ruin the experience. There is no way to sugar coat this - It just isn't fun to play.

If you have a tolarance for awful gameplay,  dreadful controls and want to experience a classic, with all of its highs and lows this game automatically becomes a recommend. However, if you are like me and eventually will end up cursing the controls, it propably isn't worth the mental strain and you should stay away. I recommend you rather watch a playthrough.

137251238.review:
Brilliant game. First playthrough was a genuinely scary experience while simultaneously being really captivating and enjoyable. Second time round, I knew what to expect so the fear factor was reduced, but it was just as, if not more, fun. Amazing environments, spooky music, and an all round great time. 
After playing as Jill, I thought a playthrough as Chris would be harder due to not getting the lockpick, extra inventory space and grenade launcher, but to be honest I found playing as Chris to be just as good and not particularly any harder with planning and inventory management. That said, I think I would probably recommend playing as Jill for a first time run. While Chris takes more hits to die and he is better at shooting, I think things like the lockpick make the early game a lot easier to settle into, with the late game being more or less the same in terms of gameplay for both characters.
I absolutely adore this game and I'd really recommend it, whether coming into it as a Resident Evil fan, or as someone new to the series. Sure things like the camera angles take getting used to and can cause some pains (especially in certain puzzles), but none of the game's difficulties or shortcomings come anywhere close to making the game not worth playing or being un-enjoyable. 
: )
