137176455.review:
[h1] Resident Evil teaches that cinematic doesn't mean uninteractive  [/h1]

In the current zeitgeist of the videogame artform, the current standards call for a certain kind of game design. Filling your game with scenes, linear segments and a certain feel that the interaction was an afterthought. Games are trying to become movies and in such process, they simply forget what made videogames so special: interaction.

[b]I'm not implying that such games shouldn't exist, or that such games are inherently bad[/b] — I'm a Metal Gear Solid fan, for fuck's sake. But I also do think that there's a model where they apply such elements without putting any thought on how to properly make the experience justifiable as a game. "Cinematic" became a really marketable adjective, but I don't think any of these recent cutscene focused games are the prime example of this quality just because they have a lot of dialogues and film-like photography. If I'm honest, [b] the most "cinematic" game I have ever played is the one you are looking for opinions right now: Resident Evil Remake. [/b]

Due to the fact this title doesn't force you to watch Hollywood inspired scenes, some people might question my statement. And these people should maybe take some time to watch more films, especially Sam Raimi, Alfred Hitchcock or George Romero's films. [b]Resident Evil Remake is the master of gamifying the experience of watching a horror thriller film through the clever usage of a philosophy the title coined: the so called "survival horror" experience.[/b] Akin to the classic Evil Dead, you are forced to explore an uncharted, lethal environment full of uncertainity. You have limited inventory slots, limited resources and the enemies you are facing are quite relentless. This game will show you how people in the 2000s viewed zombies: flesh dolls that hunt you regardless of how many shots you fired at them; it takes a lot of resources to effectively deal with them.

If you take the wrong choices, you might probably need to restart the game rather early... because even the saving system requires you to use a limited item. It never gets frustrating because the only part of the game [b]you are given full player agency and freedom to experiment is the early segments[/b] (it gets linear and less likely for you to screw up in the last levels). Still, you are always exploring, room after room, with a gun in your hand and a lot of fear of what will appear next. This game hides surprises and plays around with making you familiar with ambients to subvert this notion later, while presenting challenges in unexpected ways. Resident Evil isn't as disturbing as Silent Hill or Fatal Frame, but it's constantly a despair fest, where you are always picking resources and planning your inventory so you can travel through corridors without falling into the mansion's deadly traps. It's the apex of the classic "haunted mansion" trope, even if it avoids supernatural explanations.

This is the first part of the "survival horror" experience, and it's where you might feel frustrated and overwhelmed. However, do not give up! The second part is where you find some kind of overpowering resource, which you can abuse to dominate the game and show those zombies what you are made of. Do you remember when Ash found the shotgun in Evil Dead? You'll feel just like him when you find RE1's shotgun. You will become an overpowered action hero that is throughly able to deal with the threats that oppressed you for so long; that is, until the game throws at you new enemies, traps and puzzles. It's a constant dance of being underpowered and overpowered and it's addicting. [b]It's a masterclass on building tension, giving you consistent pay-offs and surprising you like a classic horror film.[/b]

One might ask himself about the replay value, due to the fact most of the surprises won't have the same effect if you know the mansion. [b]Resident Evil answers this by rewarding players who know the layout with unlockables, new game modes and the fact you have two campaigns.[/b] While you are exploring the same basic environment, choosing between Chris and Jill alters a lot of the resources, gameplay elements and choices you are forced into. Playing at least two times to witness different situations and twists is totally worth it — Chris being the [b]pure ludonarrative path[/b], where you are given [b]total agency of how you explore the mansion, and the game is tougher[/b]; Jill being the more [b]"linear"[/b] path, where you have [b]more resources and you don't need the same amount of backtracking and inventory management[/b], thus making the exploration a bit more of a traditional videogame since you won't need to clear your path or worry about coming back all that much.

And as a remake, it plays around a lot with the idea of [b]surprising the hardcore fan who has played the originals, changing a lot of the surprises and mixing a bit of the mansion's layout.[/b] New mechanics are added and they make the game even harder than it originally was. They also fix a lot of the issues the first game had, such as the underwhelming cave segment, the awful shark "bossfight" while adding a bit more of narrative to spice things up. I'll just say a name: [b]Lisa Trevor[/b], and you'll know what I mean when you get there. It also improves a bit on the controls, allowing you to use the analogue stick and giving you an option if you are not a fan of tank controls.

I'm more of a Chris fan because of how it plays out more akin to "living" a horror film, but both campaigns still feature the same core experience to some degree. Got around this one because I really wanted to try 4's remake, which means I rushed through the original PS1 Resident Evil and then decided to rush through this one too. But I couldn't just rush this, because [b]Resident Evil Remake is a true masterpiece and I feel very compelled to play this until there's no more content to be found.[/b] I already have 50 hours, and this game lasts like, 15~20 hours in your first run. [b] Your run can be optimized up to 2 hours or something if you do play it a lot, and it's just joyful. If you enjoy game design and haven't played this, I don't know what you are doing. This is a purchasable evidence that you can take movie elements and translate into a truly interactive and immersive game. Play it right now![/b]

[h1] 10/10 [/h1]

137079809.review:
Since this game launched on the Gamecube back in 2002, we have received a lot of RE games. Some of them ok, some of them bad, some of them good and some of them very good. But this game will always be my favorite and what I consider Resident Evil at its peak. I always revisit this game every couple of years and I'm reminded of why I love it so much.

Just a couple of things I don't like, such as too much back tracking compared to OG RE2 and OG RE3; and a couple of QOL updates that are missing from previous titles such as being able to use green herbs without needing inventory space and a dodge mechanic like OG RE 3. Other than that, this game is amazing.

I recommend playing it on a 4:3 aspect ratio instead of 16:9 Widescreen resolutions, as the pre-rendered backgrounds (Which yes, this game still uses, hence why it looks so good) will get stretched when playing on 16:9 resolutions.

136886515.review:
To honestly rate this very classic and unique horror game, I would give Resident Evil 1 somewhere between a 7.5/10 to an 8/10.

This game was truly unique and eerie in many ways, and the fact that it's also a horror game, it also brought many fun and dashing values besides constant scares. The design and graphics for this game, especially for the time it was released (in 2002) is extremely impressive. The atmosphere, the creatures, the characters, the story, the music, the places to explore, and the other elements give a true insight of what a Resident Evil game should be. 

Through my gameplay, I had lots of fun playing this, and I enjoyed the story a lot. I think the best part about this game wasn't just the horror. but the VAST exploration and unique creatures and monsters you encounter.  This game at times would go from being extremely eerie, distorting, and unnerving, to mystical, comforting, and humble. Exploring the whole premises of the mansion was truly fun and engaging. The only downfall of this game I could say, is some of the control aspects. It can be a little janky at times and many of the controls just seem very old like antiques, but it's easy to get used to and deal with. It took me like 20 minutes to get used to and then I just forgot about all of that. STILL GREAT.

If there's something I also haven't really talked about it's the SCARES. This game at times was horrifying. When it came to the Crimson Head Zombies, the sharks, Lisa Trevor, and DON'T FORGET ABOUT THE GIANT SNAKE, I found it scary as hell. Lucky I had a gun in my hand or I actually would've shat myself.

Last but not least, the characters and the story. I really liked the main characters and their future stories and games, but the voice acting and character development was a little lackluster and silly at times. Like I mean SILLY ASF. The story mixed with the development of the characters is solid by itself, and really helped build all of the other games in the future, but DAMN I can't keep mentioning how goofy a lot of the story aspects were. Well, I can't blame the story and characters for being like that, especially the fact that the game was originally released in Japan by CAPCOM in the early 2000s, with the type of action in some of these CAPCOM games being extremely serious and intense and just a little silly in general.  Other than that, the story and characters were still solid and I really enjoyed it but...this game would've been soooooo much different if it were remade in 2023.

Other than that, I recommend this game to anyone who wants to try the Resident Evil series for the first time. It's not the most perfect game, but it's definitely a great game.

136665109.review:
I really wanted to like this game more than I did. I still do recommend it regardless. It's fun, exciting, interesting, at times quite tense, and it looks fantastic, but it's extremely slow at times as you slog back and forth across areas trying to unlock doors and find items The first half is particularly slow. This is further impeded by doors that can only be opened from one direction for no particular reason. Another thing that forces you to constantly run back and forth, in this case to your saferooms, is the very limited inventory. A key takes up just as much space as a shotgun,the only thing that stacks are bullets, and I played as Chris, who can only carry six things at a time. I found the inventory management absolutely maddening. Perhaps the worst part of the game is the damn camera; every time you round a corner or approach a wall or other side of a room, the camera angle changes, and the direction you are facing with it. I had to check my map hundreds of times to figure out which way I was facing (and since you have to open your map to use the compass, the compass is pretty useless) and was constantly running the wrong way because the direction I was facing changed and suddenly I was running sideways instead of forwards. Lastly, some of the doors and places to put items are damn hard to see because they're essentially part of a matte-painting background, and if you're standing just slightly to the left or right, you can press F until the cows come home and you're not getting through that door or finding that slot to put that item. 

Overall I'd give this game a 6.5 out of ten.

136396988.review:
This game is still fantastic in 2023!

Though the limitations in movement/control may put some people off, if you treat it as just a gameplay mechanic it shouldn't hinder you from having a blast. The fixed camera will rarely create unfair situations since the encounters have been designed with it in mind, and the aim-lock provides a good (and necessary) fix to the fixed camera.

The backgrounds are a little blurry with modern higher resolutions and could use an upgrade at least to 1080p if Capcom had the originals with enough detail since they were first created for low definition TV screens, but otherwise the game still looks good thanks to its great art direction.

Just go into this conscious about what you're getting: this is not an all-out action game and expects you to advance carefully, conserve your ammo, avoid enemies altogether where it makes sense and even limits your saves (so space them out!).

I recommend starting in Normal difficulty ("Going on a hike") with Jill if this your first time and you want it a bit more challenging, or at Easy difficulty ("Taking a walk") if you want it a bit easier (easily enough ammo to dispose of every enemy). Also if you don't find vertical black bars intolerable I recommend playing in 4:3 as I find the pan-and-scan method the game uses if you choose widescreen pretty distracting. Also, read the game manual as it'll contain the kind of information that you'd otherwise get from an initial tutorial section in modern games.

136361116.review:
Resident Evil: Remake was a fun challenge, in a sense that the camera and item management is your worst nightmare compared to the plethora of monsters lurking within the Spencer mansion. This is as close as I have come to playing the "Original" style of Resident Evil Games, since what I've seen online is that this is almost a 1 to 1 remake with some minor changes here and there.

Fixed camera is a part of this franchise's history some people don't like, but I think it worked here. There were moments for sure where controlling my character felt a little frustrating because the camera would either keep switching to a location I wasn't trying to go or downright not show where an enemy was. I got used to it eventually but man did it feel like the camera was against me multiple times. This isn't a bad thing actually in my eyes as it was funny most of the time, its just a part of the franchise's history that I think every fan should try at least once.

Item management on the other hand sucked, I did my first run as Jill and only had 8 slots of inventory compared to Chris' 6 slots. And let me tell you two extra slots didn't mean the game was easier to get through as the backtracking in this felt atrocious sometimes, but nothing I couldn't manage. Again like fixed camera I think this is something every fan of this franchise should try once. Also, I played this game without the mod that removes the door opening scenes and it honestly wasn't too bad once I got used to it. 

So I guess my biggest point to takeaway with this game is that you should try it out at least once, and everything just takes some getting used to!

136165131.review:
As someone who has previously played Resident Evil 7 and always watched others play some other RE games, I've always wondered how it would be playing them from the very beginning and having that first hand experience with the game that completely changed or even created an entire genre of games, a game that set the example and was the role model and inspiration for so many others.

It blew my mind. Absolutely crazy how DAMN GOOD this game is, even tho I played the remake and not the original one, this was one hell of an experience. Highlights of the game for me and what I believe the game also shifts its focus too are BY FAR the puzzles and the level/game design.
Can't really describe the feeling of how rewarding it is to understand what's needed to solve a puzzle sometimes putting together informations from some other rooms to solve a specific one. 
Also really rewarding to finally unlock that locked door that was bothering you and seeing how each room connects to another one that you'll later realize and go "ohhh so that's where this leaded to, it makes so much sense!". 

Heavily recommend playing this game and just enjoying it to the fullest, the atmosphere is great, it has no jumpscares which I loved and even tho the game is able to maintain the fear of the unknown and of what could happen because of its atmosphere, storyline and again, level and game design. 

What a blast, on my way to play the next ones in line!

135868484.review:
This game is the Gold Standard of what remakes should be. It stays faithful to the mechanics and plot of the original game, while making multiple improvements (most obviously graphics). I liked that it kept the controls and UI of the old RE games, instead of following the RE4 formula like the RE2 and RE3 remakes did. I would have loved to have seen an RE2 and RE3 remake along the same lines as RE1 HD because the first three original RE games (1, 2, and 3: Nemesis) were a huge part of my childhood.  

This game is probably the hardest of the classic RE games as it takes more time to complete the puzzles, locate key items, acquire resources to defeat enemies, and so on compared to other modern RE games. But because of that, it's immensely rewarding when you finish a section and you are able to progress onto the next. (Especially when you can finally get rid of a certain terrifying enemy that can't be killed with guns).

In short, if you enjoyed the old RE games, you will enjoy RE1 HD. No doubt about it.

This game is an absolute gem that truly deserves recognition. Initially, I must admit that the controls and camera angles did not feel natural to me and seemed to be working against my actions, which made it challenging to get into at first. However, after spending some time with it, I found myself having a genuinely enjoyable experience. Although I still believe that RE2 is currently the pinnacle of the series (at least until I give RE4 a try), this game is undoubtedly a remarkable achievement and easily one of the best debut games in the history of gaming.

If you're already a fan of the Resident Evil franchise, or even if you're looking for a new game to delve into, I highly recommend giving this one a shot. The remaster treatment it received is fantastic, and the game boasts a plethora of charm and soul, not to mention an expertly crafted immersive atmosphere. It's a truly masterful example of how to make a game that truly immerses the player and draws them in.

135458814.review: Man for someone experiencing the original Resident Evil in 2023 its crazy that people figured any of this out in the 90s before walkthroughs existed it gets so convoluted. There's a lot that has aged pretty poorly, namely the laughably small inventory and the tedium of managing it while picking up every item because your resources are limited, but your pockets are even moreso. Dialogue is bad enough to be funny in numerous cases (I played through Jill's campaign) which was fun but frustrating because I would have liked to see how well the story could have been told if it went better. Graphically and gameplay wise the game holds up well as two of this game's major strengths, it looks great and feels good to move and shoot (not at the same time.) Worth noting that I did experience several crashes throughout my 10ish hours of playing, usually when tabbing between applications so do be warned. Was my experience with thus game fun? Sometimes for sure but there got to be a lot of tedium and/or confusion between those moments so while I didn't fall in love with Resident Evil I will give it a Recommended out of appreciation for its impact on gaming and horror overall.

135089910.review:
Wait... a Negative Review??  Well I had little choice, but don't get me wrong either, the GameCube Original is a PHENOMENAL GAME, I love it, I even did Invisible Mode on Hard as a Let's Play.  Resident Evil 1 Remake is a masterpiece that really should be played by everyone, it's one of these games that you almost never get tired of on repeated playthroughs, it's very seldom these days.

But oh well, my goal here isn't really to go in-depth with the base game itself for now, and I want you to understand that any Version stemming from the GameCube will do, HOWEVER my point with this Review is I'm comparing between the GC Version and this HD Remaster, as this HD Version is SUPPOSED to be a further improved version of the GameCube Original, and while HD is pretty faithful to GC, almost like a Port, well by evidence of my score, I would rather recommend you the GC one, if you can get it that is.

The changes and even additions for HD are what I actually take issue with.  It really doesn't add much to the Original, aside from Leaderboards that I believe don't even work due to hackers, and there is 1 new Costume for both Chris and Jill, they get their attire from RE5, but I think they were very lazily included in RE1; Chris isn't meant to be as old and experienced-looking as he does in RE5, and while I get Costumes are supposed to be a bit silly at times, I feel the RE5 skins miss the mark, they do not really follow the aesthetic of the Original's, and Chris is pretty much getting a SECOND military outft.  I still appreciate though that I can choose a Costume before starting a New Game, rather than going to the Closet every playthrough.

The backgrounds have been re-rendered or upscaled and, for the most part, they do have more details for larger resolutions than if you would put GC on an Emulator, plus there isn't the slight loading lag between each screens (not rooms, screens in a single room), so HD actually saves time on the loading times.  However, this is where hell breaks loose, the backgrounds were never made wider from what they originally were to fit the new 16:9 Aspect Ratio, they are sliced at the top and bottom edges of the screen to fit horizontally, and to make sure the S.T.A.R.S. don't disappear at the top or bottom, the camera can moves up or down to follow them, but this is [b]freaking awful[/b], I tried it for a while and it's just making me sick, and you're still missing crucial information offscreen wherever you go.  So, word of advice, play on 4:3 (which isn't even the Default), because then you'll see everything and the screens stay still, you're not going to get vertigo with that.

I also hinted at upscaling, which yeah, some backgrounds don't look that great, for example the Knights Room looks pixely in certain parts, and they even removed smaller details like a bug that was in GC, on a tree as you're about to enter the Lab, so I gotta wonder if even more details were lost in the HD transition.

Other aesthetic changes and this is where the changes hurt me the most; some of the musics on GC were altered in HD, like Rush of Horror and Concrete Bound, which were my favorites.  I... really don't like these new versions, they're not bad, but they were much better on GC IMO, felt more moody, and there is no way to revert these changes.  I do not understand why they did it.

Then, the addition of "Modernized" Controls (Alternate), as people seem to loathe the Original's Tank Controls, which for sure they need some getting used to, but they're perfectly fine for the most part, the Resident Evil Series tend to be at its best when the characters are very restricted in their movement, and if anything it has always stayed CONSISTENT.

When you use the Alternate Controls, the characters no longer have to turn sideways to then move forward, they simply Run towards wherever you aim the Control Stick at, and that makes navigation go "slightly" faster.  However, Alternate really breaks the game, it's very easy now to bait enemies to attack you and run past them when they miss, it really trivializes a lot of the base game and goes against the roots of the series, but eh I can't hide that it was somewhat fun to psyche out the enemies so often, but I still take issue that it breaks what made the OG special in its own way.

Where shit hits the fan again is when the screens change, because remember the characters move towards where you're moving the Stick, meaning that if a screen is orientated to the East, then the movement is no longer true as the next screen shifts towards the North.  The band-aid to this issue is that, as long as you keep the Stick in place when screens change, the character will keep going in that direction, so it doesn't always happen where you end up accidentally going back to the previous screen, for the most part you're able to reorient yourself.  However, notice my wording, because yes, there are still problems that arise from this system regardless; I would go down an hallway, and as I'm about to make the turn, I want to go left, but then the screen changes, meaning that I'm going left from the new screen's perspective, MEANING I'm going back to the previous screen!  And this happens REGULARLY, so much so that you'll often have no clue WTH Chris or Jill are doing, you'll end up doing circles as you fight with the Controls and this might allow a cheap shot from enemies.  Even in spite of said band-aid, this can get maddening.

Lastly, my other problem with Alternate is that there is no dedicated Run Button; of course you may Walk by tilting the Control Stick only slightly, and there is "almost" no reasons to walk (aside from maybe stealth?), so what is it then?  Well again notice I highlighted "almost", in the Original, if you mash the Run button when you're going up or down stairs, you actually climb them MUCH faster, and you may not think about it, but there are A LOT of stairs.  Well, you may finally realize that doing it with the Control Stick is impossible, and the Dead Zone for Walking is so small anyway you wouldn't be able to Walk in normal context.  There is also a part where you need to move an item to its destination purely by walking, meaning once again that fine-tuning movement on Alternate would be unwise.

The Original Controls never encounter these Modern problems, and so, I must say that, even if you activate Alternate, you can still play with the OG Controls at any time when using the D-Pad, and THAT has a dedicated Run Button.  So say Chris and Jill start having seizures due to screen changes, you can play with both Alternate and Original Controls at all times, depending on the situation.  The problem here isn't that I need to change my Options, but rather I would've preferred to Walk with the Control Stick as is, then use the Run Button to run.  Maybe you don't like holding a button all the time just to do something so trivially simple as Running, but... I just want my goddamn Run Button, it's awkward going from Control Stick to D-Pad just for when I go up or down stairs as I need to stop for a second.

Still though, if you want to avoid any and all problems I've encountered using Alternate Controls, you can simply use the Original instead, meaning you'd be always on Tank Controls, but everything will stay consistent.

So afterall, I have many issues with this HD Remaster, which is kind of a shame because the 60fps and some of the Higher-Res Backgrounds would almost make it worth it, but there are some parts of the upscaling that look ugly, some of the musics are worse now, and then there are the many problems of the Alternate Controls.  The HD Remaster isn't worth it when put against the GameCube Version, so if you can get GC, just get GC (not sure about Wii).  However, in this day and age, it may be hard for you to get your hands on the GameCube Version, let alone the hardware, so you can still enjoy Resident Evil 1 Remake thanks to this HD Remaster, it's just not going to be my Version of choice.

135070728.review:
[h1]Resident Evil Remake - A Classic Reborn[/h1]

[b]TL;DR[/b]: A true classic reborn for modern times. The remake looks and plays fantastically, bringing the survival horror genre to new heights. As someone who owns every Resident Evil game ever released, I can say this is a must-have for any fan of the series.

I've been a fan of the Resident Evil series since its inception, and I can confidently say that the Resident Evil Remake is one of the best entries in the series. The game looks and plays fantastically, with updated graphics and controls that bring the classic survival horror gameplay to modern times.

The atmosphere is thick with tension and fear, and the updated visuals only enhance the experience. Whether you're a fan of the original or new to the series, the Resident Evil Remake is a must-play.

As someone who owns every Resident Evil game ever released, I can attest to the fact that this is one of the most faithful and well-executed remakes of a classic game. The attention to detail and the respect for the source material is evident in every aspect of the game.

Overall, I highly recommend the Resident Evil Remake to anyone looking for a thrilling survival horror experience. It's a classic reborn, and it's a must-have for any fan of the series.

135064648.review:
The first Resident Evil game I ever played was Resident Evil 4 (RE4) on ye olde Gamecube. In that game, you're encouraged to fight enemies because they drop items/currency. In this game, it's usually more worthwhile to avoid enemies because all they drop in this game is your precious ammo count. 

Compared to RE4, this game is more of a puzzle-horror game than an action-horror game. The static camera angles in this game can be very disorienting but I got used to it after a bit. With the very limited item space -- 8 for one character and only 6 for the other -- it feels like this game is trolling you at times. 

The map/level design in this game is very captivating. With all of the shortcuts and pathways, it's almost like a metroidvania. Also I think some parts/puzzles in this game are very obtuse. I don't feel any shame in admitting that I used a guide for most of the game. 

I definitely recommend this game.

134860528.review:
“You have once again entered the world of survival horror...”

Resident Evil is a great remake of the iconic original version that shares the same name, you play as either Chris Redfield or Jill Valentine, two members of the elite unit S.T.A.R.S. that have been sent into the Arklay mountains from Raccoon City in order to investigate a bizarre string of murders and the disappearance of their fellow members in Bravo team. After encountering monsters in the mountains and having their pilot take off without them, they seek refuge in a mansion in order to survive.

Both Chris and Jill have a unique scenario with different encounters and gameplay differences, choosing when to use certain resources like ammo and healing items is a major part of the survival horror gameplay, sometimes running past a zombie or cerberus is a better decision than using ammo so that you can save it later when you face a more dangerous encounter. While exploring the Spencer Mansion, you will also have to solve numerous puzzles which is another major part of the gameplay in Resident Evil.

Some newcomers may be put off from the fixed camera angles and tank controls, but I heavily urge for those who feel that way to give them a chance as they're a unique way to control the gameplay and help showcase the beautiful hand crafted environments (just make sure to use the original controls and aspect ratio as the updated ones feel very loose and change how you were meant to control the game, plus the upscaled backgrounds can feel too stretched out at times making them look worse).

Overall this is a fantastic entry in the series that provides a good challenge and has plenty of replayability just like other entries in the series and similar games in the genre. If you plan on getting into the Resident Evil franchise or have a friend who's interested, then this is one of the best places to start.

134685791.review:
I haven't beaten it yet, but I can tell you that this game nails the survival-horror genre unlike anything I've seen before.
I'm a total wuss, and I thought this game wouldn't be scary considering it's age. Man was I wrong, It's terrifying to put it simply. Absolutely terrifying,
The atmosphere and general gameplay all contribute to the creep-factor in their own ways, even the way the type-writer sounds is done with care to the atmosphere. It's genuinely the scariest mansion I've ever experienced in a game, the lighting and sound design is phenomenal as well. It's not hyper realistic or anything, but it nails what it's trying to accomplish. spooking you, 
The way the zombies behave in this game is very simple, however your decisions greatly determine how much of a threat they are. If you play smart, the game will reward you. However, if you rush this game and kill everything in sight. There'll be nasty consequences, It's a very rewarding system and it forces you to really take in the horror they lovingly built in to every little detail. 
The jump scares are very well done, and the general scares throughout the game hold up well enough. 
The only complaint I have is the voice acting, why'd they have to take away the god-tier voice overs from the original game? I was excited to be appointed the master of unlocking by barry but was rudely dissappointed.
Amazing game overall, a must have for any horror-lover. 
Also general advice for any new players, get the background music fix-mod before playing. It'll make your experience way better as the remakes music is broken and annoying. Not sure why they pitched it up so much but it ruins the music,

This game is a fantastic remake to the original but it has its flaws. The voice acting isn't very good, the tank controls are annoying, and the fixed angles can be cool, but are really buggy. El juego es una verdadera obra de arte, aunque no para impacientes..

8/10.

134268577.review:
TL/DR: Jill Sandwich and Boulder-Puncher trespass into a private mansion, kill all the residents and destroy all the evidence with no repercussions. 10/10 experience. 

I am not a fan of zombies games in general but Resident Evil may be my only exception. This right here is the perfect example of how to do a remaster of an outdated game. Not only does Resident Evil improve from the 1996 version, it also adds new features to keep players tense.

[h1] Story [/h1]
There are two playable characters in Resident Evil, Jill Valentine and Chris Redfield. Both characters have relatively different campaigns however key events such as finding items or fighting boss almost play identically which is fairly disappointing so don't bother trying to figure out any RE lore from this game. 

[h1] Gameplay [/h1] 
One of the things that kept me from playing this game initially were complaints from RE fans about the fixed camera and tank controls but I personally never experiences any issues with it. Personally, I think the fixed camera perspectives makes the game more cinematic and intense when navigating through the mansion. 


[h1] Graphics [/h1] 
For a game which was originally released in 2002 on the gamecube, the graphics have aged relatively well.

This is the fifth game in my Resident Evil binge that I've been on, and I have to say this game is fantastic. It should be noted that if you are planning on playing these games, you should definitely start with this one. 

Anyway, this was my first time playing a game with a fixed camera angle like this, and at first it was significantly annoying. Once you get used to it, I feel like it is better for immersion. The story is great and like any other Resident Evil, you will need multiple playthroughs to complete everything. You can play as Chris or Jill, who have slightly altered storylines. There are multiple endings and possible outcomes depending on what you do during the playthrough.

I have never played the original version of this game but everyone seems to think that it honors the original game with updated graphics. Some of the cut scenes in this game are rendered in very low quality but outside of that the graphics are great. 

Seeing as the Resident Evil games typically go on sale, this would be a great pick up. However, I think this game is fully worth the price. Fantastic game that will keep your hands full in the beginning if never played before, and will be very rewarding in the end. 

9/10

133243330.review:
You’re surrounded by monsters. Your only weapon is a handgun. The only people left to fight are your fellow survivors and the relentless, bloodthirsty hordes. The desperate need to survive is all that keeps you going, even if you’re terrified of your own shadow.

These are the facts. Not the fun of surviving on a post-apocalyptic, zombie-infested Earth, of course. The rest is window dressing. This is pure survival horror, a genre defined by the necessity to pay off some nameless, frustrating threat with your heart, mind, and soul. The genre calls on you to prepare for conflict, endure pain, and endure fear – in order to live a life worth living.

Survival horror is defined by the main character being bullied, put in a position where they have to survive on their own. The relentless AI and difficulty of beating a level make the mechanic of surviving seem simple, even boring. But it’s not. It’s just more challenging than most people want it to be.

So it goes with the Resident Evil remake, which is a game that tries to create a slow burn of terror, following you from room to room as you rescue other people from hordes of enemies. It tries to make the player feel uncomfortable, and to make the action-focused combat satisfying, but you don’t feel threatened or heroic or feared or like an exceptional combatant. Instead, you’re just relieved to make it out of a room alive.

133217324.review:
Second game of my chronological play through of the resident evil game series.

There is not much I can say besides how great this game is. It is practically the game that defined the Survival Horror franchise and still holds up beautifully. I am aware of the re-playability of this game and it looks great, but I that may be a future me adventure.

The Good:
I love the pre-rendered backgrounds, for me it just looks so much better and gets high praise for me.
SFX are amazing and really adds greatly to the game world. Combat was fun for the age and felt rewarding to dispose of zombies properly. Puzzles are great and I enjoyed them. Honestly can't say too much, It is a staple of it's time. I adore this game.

The Bad:
Not much to say besides minor things, got the mod this time to skip door animations, should be a given in the menu. 

The Ugly: 
In my reviews, the ugly is what I disliked the most, and what I disliked most was how forced it felt to have the main character alone. You meet a friendly and they die a minute later or when one it suppose to stay alive they decide to split up 2 seconds later. Just happened way to much that I never expected any help from anyone. I know it can add to the horror that you are all by yourself but it is just the logic of sticking together? It just happened way too much.

Conclusion:
It is the game that defined survival horror. I will give it so much credit for a game genre I love so much. 10/10 for me. I know this is the remake of the original and adapted, but I will treat it as if it was the original.

133215186.review:
A classic and true survival horror game with zombies. Trapped in the Spencer Mansion, you'll have to navigate the mansion's dozen of unlocked rooms, and unlock the rest of the rooms, solve many puzzles, eliminate/evade many zombies. 

Zombies aren't easily eliminated, they'll need to be headshotted (which can be difficult) or burned otherwise they comeback even stronger and faster, but regardless the player won't have enough resources to kill them all. Besides zombies, there's a great variety of other enemies/bosses. Tons of cinematic moments to experience with the cut scenes as well unique to your playthrough with the fixed camera perspective (surveillance camera viewpoint). One complaint I would have for the game is that I found moving through multiple camera angles can be awkward sometimes. Tons of replayability given different routes with Chris and Jill , amazing cinematic moments, and hard to navigate Spencer Mansion.

Definitely a game worth purchasing , its from 2002 but looks amazing and plays well. More survival horror than action like future RE titles (which are also great).

132403871.review:
When I was 9 years old I was in another state at a distant cousins house, who happened to have a Playstation. There were a few different games to choose from, but one cover stood out: a haunting image of a ghoul peering over its shoulder at you, that struck me with fear and curiosity. We popped the CD in, turned off the lights, and with my cousins spectating all around me, I dared to venture into the Spencer Mansion for the first time, and discovering the horrors within. It was that moment I became a Resident Evil fan.

Being 8 years old, and not having access to the internet or any strategy guide, I didn't get far. The mansion was [i]massive[/i] and honestly it took me minutes to muster up the courage to see what was on the other side of every door I found myself in front of. I don't think I got much further than discovering the back gate to the courtyard before it was time to go home.

Cut to Christmas, quite a few years later: I get a Gamecube, and the Resident Evil remake that had just released on it. I was [i]ecstatic.[/i] Finally I was going to return to the Spencer Mansion, and it was going to be even scarier. And holy hell, was it scarier. I owned that game for years, and even then, I still couldn't get further than the courtyard. The crimson head mechanic alone gave me so much anxiety and terror that playing the game was an exercise in self-abuse. I've made many attempts--even on the easiest mode! But I still. Could not. Beat it.

Now, these games are classics. If you're on the fence of trying this game out, whether it be the fixed-camera, or the puzzles, or the anxiety: I urge you to play and beat this game at least once. Explore the world within: read the documents. Unravel the mystery of [i]what the hell happened here.[/i] And reach the satisfying ending.

132268803.review:
I'm decidedly a purist when it comes to games, preferring the original version over remakes the majority of the time; even if graphics improve, the other qualities that make a game good tend to not age and remakes have a habit of harming the charm of the original in more than a few ways. Given this bias, I'm nevertheless struggling to come up with areas the remake doesn't straight up improve on. My main complaints would be that the OST is a little weaker in the remake and there's a few rooms, particularly in the guardhouse that are creepier in the original. Even so, when compared to the amount of new content and mechanics added to the game, and how much more realistic it looks, I have to admit its better.

That being said, for those who have never played either, I would still recommend playing the 1996 release first. Despite replacing the original in a lot of ways, it also feels like a complimentary piece, as there are a lot of changes to the puzzles and surprises that feel like they were tailor-made to throw off veteran players.

132044697.review:
A must play for classic survival horror fans.

This is one of the most well thought out and intricately designed games I have ever played. You are constantly forced to strategize and make decisions. What items should I carry? Is there a safer way to get where I need to go? Do I need to spend ammo here or can I run around these enemies? Should I just take the damage here or fight back? It's a much smarter game than the memes and OG voice acting would have you believe.

This is one of the few games to me where knowing it back to front makes it more replayable rather than tedious and boring.

I'd also recommend at least trying the tank controls, because the alternate breaks the game in more ways than one. There's also a mod to skip door animations if that's a deal breaker.

131922841.review:
Resident Evil released in 1996 for the PS1, then Capcom gave it a proper remake in 2002 for the GameCube, the same year Resident Evil 0 released. Both the REmake, and RE0, received HD remasters and were ported to modern systems 1/19/2015 and 1/19/2016. There are QoL updates, but for the most part, they're the exact same games from 02', making them 20 years old at this point, nearing 21 years. I just replayed it to confirm that I still enjoy it. The alternate controls make it possible to strafe and will be more familiar with modern/new players, but don't make the mistake of using the keyboard like I did. Use a controller as the game was created for it analog sticks. 

This era of RE is much slower pace, more puzzles and backtracking, and just thorough exploration of the Spencer mansion. References of characters, like Ada, are made, and it's nice to notice these small details and thinking, "oh, right, Ada from RE2 with Leon and RE4." The same thing is true for WIlliam Burkin and the G-Virus and other notable characters, even a slight reference to an arm wrestling competition from a poster and the winner becoming the Police Chief, who you see in RE2. The game is definitely more focused on terror and feeling uncomfortable, rather than repetitive jump scares. It's immersive and almost suffocating playing it for the first time, in the dark, with the music cranked up. It appealed to veterans who played the original. The infamous "dog jumps through the window" scene happens, but in a different way. When you think it's going to happen, and the camera angle in a certain hallway is practically telling you it will, something hits the window and the glass cracks, but no dogs jump through. This sort of appreciation isn't possible for new players, but it still provides a lot of tension, as many camera angles make it feel like you're being watched or something will jump through the windows. This will often turn out to be the case at some point in the game. Right before fighting Yawn the giant snake, it looks like something is watching you through the window. When you backtrack, it shows that he shattered and made his way through that very same window. The attention to detail in this game still amazes me, and even though it is 2 decades old, I had a lot of fun. I really hope it receives another remake, one comparable to RE2R, to really feel the game in a modern take on the RE engine. 

If you like to work your brain a bit, explore and immerse yourself in a dark mansion, take in the story, and even have a lot of replayability, buy this game. It's $4.99 right now, and so is RE0.

131804989.review:
This review needs some backstory, so bare with it if you have the time to read. Otherwise, just skip to the actual review part.

Ever since I watched the first Resident Evil film staring Milla Jovovich, in my good old teen days, I realised three things. One, I had a mad crush on the celebrity ([i]don't worry, I got out of it[/i]). Two, zombie movies and games are kick-ass. Three, I really needed more Resident Evil in my life.

When I learnt that there was a Resident Evil game, I was stoked and couldn't wait to actually get hold of one of the titles. To my disappointment, it wasn't available on PC, I wasn't going to own a PS at the time, and none of my friends actually owned a copy, not to mention... no Alice as the main character.

My first actual entry to the game was Resident Evil 4 and although it wasn't nearly what I expected and it featured way less horror and zombies, it was actually a great game and I thoroughly enjoyed playing through the game and learning that the films are actually not even close to what the originals on PS were set out to be, so of course I started doing some digging and realised how much I've been missing out. After the release of the RE3 film, things just mostly went downhill in quality for me and overall the films just mostly suck and are completely over the top getting worse with each entry after RE2. The worse the films got, the more interesting the games became, but the problem remained that I didn't have a console to play on. Fortunately, the remaster came to Steam and it would take until now for me to actually play the game and I have to say that my mind has been blown by how much I actually missed out on over the years.

[b]Now we can actually start with the review![/b]

Are you in the mood for gaming as they were in the good old days ([i]or maybe you need to just experience it for the first time[/i]? A time when games didn't tell you jack shit other than throw you into the deep end and expect you to figure things out for yourself. Where there was no such thing as press F to salute, or sudden hints when the game realises that you're taking too long to solve a puzzle. Well, Resident Evil HD is definitely the game you're looking for!

Although I never experienced the original, I can tell that they've stayed true to the time period it was created. You're literally thrown into this mansion where you know ABSOLUTELY NOTHING! Not a single hint about which character you should start with for beginners ([i]Jill is the answer[/i]), not that knifes are basically completely useless throughout the game and especially not telling you where you should go or how to solve puzzles or trap rooms. It's brutal, but goodness me is it some of the most engaging and fun experiences I've had with a game in years! 

The funny part is, the game is actually easy to play and very straightforward. The camera angles might take some getting used to, but it's mostly as simple as aim in direction and shoot. It'll hit the target... maybe not where you want it to, but it'll hit the target. Repeat until collapse and enemy is done... or is it? Having a tough time finding your way? Are there too many locked doors? Have you truly explored all the nooks and crannies? Have you examined your items? These simple features are what makes this game golden in my view. The developers trusted that the players would be able to figure things out for themselves without giving them too many flashy screen hints, or some voice hints or whatever modern games do nowadays, even if it meant hours of running in circles, the player would eventually figure it out. Now I have to admit, I "mostly" did the game by myself. I never used a walkthrough on any of the puzzles, but when wanting to save time, it helps knowing which items you should carry, because your inventory is pretty small, but I swear almost everything else was my own work. Not that I'll judge casual players for using walkthroughs during hard times, because some of the puzzles, or at least navigating the map at times requires a pointer or two, but again as mentioned, the game doesn't really give that much and your memory plays a big role in progression.

The graphics is nothing impressive in modern standards, but it's definitely an awesome art style that had me pausing a few times just to see the view of a room. It has a somewhat realistic feel to it and it's very eerie at times being in this mansion with zombies that at times jump at you from corners you couldn't see because of the camera angle. You can definitely tell the game is dated, but I think it's one of those masterpieces that will continue the test of time.

If you play as Jill, you'll experience her cutscenes with her partner, giving you the best story experience of the game, while Chris is meant for the more veteran players with less story cutscenes ([i]if at all since I only did the first zombie with Chris[/i]. In both cases, you'll learn more about the game by collecting files and reading notes explaining the origins of the zombies, what happened in the mansion, why your team got sent there in the first place and probably how all the events spilled over into RE2.

There aren't many negatives for me with this game, especially keeping in mind that it's a remaster of a very old game, but if I had to criticise, I'd say that the inventory at times even with Jill felt too small and Chris has two slots less. On normal, I picked up way more ammo than I ever needed and honestly, I mostly conserved because I expected something that'll force me to use most of my ammo, but that never happened. I'm sure on harder difficulties it gets worse. Finally, the voice acting is pretty bad :D but honestly that's just trying to find fault, I don't really care about that all too much. Probably the most annoying feature is when every room or area you enter, it always has to play a slow scene of you opening the door, or climbing the ladder, or taking the elevator up and down. I'm sure there were reasons back then, but it's frustrating when backtracking.

I'm happy that I finally got to play the first entry and I'm now ready to continue to RE2, a game I've been looking forward to playing since release but left it off because I wanted to get through the whole franchise. No doubt I'll reinstall this game in the future and attempt to gain the rest of the achievements. It's just one of those games that deserves to be replayed!

131780702.review:
[h1]Resident Evil has captured a unique form of horror only video games can achieve.[/h1]
My experience with the Resident Evil franchise is a new journey I set myself on toward the end of 2022. I was always aware of the series, but I couldn’t go as far as to name a character or describe the games past shooting zombies. While my personal opinions on each entry generally align with the average fan, the franchise’s roots hold the strongest grip on me. The original 1996 release is widely recognized as the pioneer of the survivor horror genre. Spawning hundreds of sequels, spinoffs, and adaptations, RE1 itself was remade in 2002 as REmake and that’s the version that was ported to Steam. Discussing the game is rather difficult as I simultaneously think this game is both one of the best and worst I’ve ever played.

Despite starting its own genre, REmake plays most similarly to a traditional point-and-click adventure game. The primary focus is on exploring the map and using the items you find to solve various puzzles. Even the enemies can be simplified as a form of puzzle interaction as effectively eliminating them resorts to spending the right resource or seeing them as just an obstacle to dodge. Sounds simple enough, but this game is a nightmare to play, and I don’t just say this because it’s scary. REmake has some of the worst design choices you will ever see. There are well over a hundred items and your inventory is confined to a mere 8 or 6 slots depending on which character you play. The maximum carrying capacity might as well be lower since you're going to have to play with 1 or 2 empty slots so you can even pick stuff up. This issue is exacerbated when you realize key items aren’t exempt from this rule. You will have no idea what you should bring unless you have a guide or have played the game before. An especially egregious example happens minutes after starting the game. You’ll find a blue gem from shoving a statue off a cliff and if you carry it with you until you need it, it’ll be in your inventory for half the game. Other items you wouldn’t expect to take up inventory space still do. Few items beside ammo are stackable, and if you want to bring more ammo than your magazine can fit it’ll cost you an item slot. Even something like SAVING requires an item. And every resource in the game is finite, meaning not only can you screw yourself up to the point where you’re out of bullets, but you might also have to start a save file from scratch simply from wasting your saves. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2904216363
Exploration is the other key component of REmake’s gameplay, and players are going to be incentivized to look around more when the environments look amazing. For what was natively a GameCube release, the Spencer Mansion looks absolutely stunning, and I find how they achieved this to be really interesting. The backgrounds are pre-rendered static images which lets the game look gorgeous while taking only an ounce of performance from the actual hardware. Think of how cutscenes look way better than the actual gameplay for games from the early to late 2000s. The art direction is phenomenal and the mansion you find yourself trapped in for the entire game felt like a real place because of it. Navigating areas and scrounging for resources never felt like a chore because every frame was a painting. Even the loading transitions were somewhat more immersive than what you’d see back in the day. It’s just a little cutscene of a door opening to cover up the load time. However these genius artistic decisions have had irreversible damage on the actual gameplay. Since the environment is static, the camera angles are fixed. Fighting a zombie in one room could have you repositioning through several camera changes, which makes seeing the enemy much more difficult. Larger rooms with zombies to fight are frustratingly hard when the camera is not in your control. And those cute lil’ door cutscenes I mentioned earlier? They’re completely unnecessary with modern hardware and aren’t skippable without the use of mods.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2904216520
Usually, these problems would be written off as bad game design and make for an awful experience, but in REmake’s case it actually somehow improves the experience in a completely different way. While the game is pretty clunky, that also makes it infinitely scarier. I think my favorite problem is with the ink ribbons. I find that a lot of horror games lose their scare factor when I can trial and error my way through a tough encounter by loading from a quicksave. When you die too much in a horror game, you lose immersion. And despite the mechanics actively working against you at times, it’s not really that difficult. This is something I feel like the later games don’t replicate as they’re either significantly harder or completely lack the feature. My death counter was only just about to leave the single digits and only one of those involving a plant would I call unfair. Dying in REmake was genuinely scary to me because there were actual consequences to it. And the enemies being oftentimes obscured by the camera worked towards the spook factor as well. There are several moments like when you enter a bathroom where the sound design alerts you to an upcoming threat that I don’t think could be found with a free camera. Combat in horror games generally has to be clunky or else I don’t think you’ll fear combating the numerous enemies. The camera is the factor that makes fighting harder, and in a weird way, I enjoyed that. That aforementioned horror REmake captures so perfectly was only achievable because of its faults. And a quick note about those aforementioned problems although I rarely like mentioning it in reviews, modding is a solution. Especially for skipping the door animations.

As for some final notes on the soundtrack and story. Horror games usually don’t have songs I’d listen to outside of the game, but REmake is a notable exception. The save room theme is the biggest highlight. It’s an incredibly soothing track with some distant howling playing in the background, a perfect representation of temporary safety. Guardhouse 1 and Neptune Tank are some other personal favorites that aren’t focused on the fear factor alone. That’s not to say the rest of OST isn’t fitting for quaking in your boots. One song has a nearly inaudible moan that most people won’t even actively pick up on. As for the story, don’t expect REmake’s writing to be the selling point for you. Like plenty of other older games, it’s there but it’s not really fleshed out. Spoilers I guess, but I doubt anyone doesn’t at least know about the series’ big bad. I really like that the zombies are man-made. RE’s zombie viruses have possibly my favorite lore and origins for undead infections. I find the idea of researchers creating zombies more in the realm of realism than them just appearing or any supernatural explanation which would be much less interesting. 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RRQI9GlGjsE
Resident Evil Remake, despite its numerous and very glaring flaws, is something I would change next to nothing about. It’s a game that I think everyone should at least try playing at least once. You don’t have to beat it, but at least give it a shot. This game is one of the scariest I’ve played and I highly recommend it because of that. [b]I’m giving the game a 7/10, but do not let that score trick you. While I have played dozens, if not hundreds, of better mechanically put-together games, none of them are going to stick in my head as long as REmake undoubtedly will.[/b]

131560251.review:
[h1]Welcome To Survival Horror[/h1]

Resident Evil is a survival horror video game developed by Capcom Production Studio 4 and published by Capcom. Resident Evil (on Steam and Gamecube) is a Remake of the 1996 PlayStation game Resident Evil, the first installment in the Resident Evil video game series. The story takes place in 1998 near the fictional Midwestern town of Raccoon City where a series of bizarre murders have taken place. The player takes on the role of either Chris Redfield or Jill Valentine, S.T.A.R.S. agents sent in by the city to investigate the murders.

[table]
    [tr]
        [th]About[/th]
        [th]Description[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]💾Graphics[/td]
        [td]Resident Evil Remake is a huge upgrade from the original. With a darker and scarier atmosphere, you will feel dread in every room with the haunting presence of a scary and haunting past the Spencer Mansion holds. With every hallway and room keeping you on edge, the map design is something truly special and I would go far and say near perfection. Some issues do occur such as some blurry textures that feel more rushed than others, but luckily there is a HD texture project you can install to improve them, but not too worry since most of the areas look really sharp and stunning. Not to mention the incredible lighting this game delivers. A true masterpiece in terms of a Remake in the graphics department. Just look up the original and compare it the remake, it’s insane![/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🎮Gameplay[/td]
        [td]This is what Survival Horror is all about! The inventory management is so good here. Having to plan every trip you take is well balanced. The safe room is your, well, safe haven. Being able to store items is a great feature Resident Evil has brought to the table. The storage box even transfers all items to every safe room so no need to go to the old storage box (except for “Real Survival” Game Mode), an amazing idea that has aged so well even for today. Both Jill and Chris have their own pro’s and con’s that makes them both feel unique from each other, even their story lines are different in some ways which is really cool to see here. Taking down zombies and other terrifying enemies will put you through one crazy experience not many games capture well today. The gunplay is simple, but works well here. The movement can be kinda tricky, but you adapt pretty quickly. Beating the game will grant you unlockables, such as weapons, costumes, and new game modes. The game is unforgiving and the only way to save is through ink ribbons, which you only have a set amount in the game so save wisely. Also there are no checkpoints so if you haven’t saved in a while, prepare to make that long journey again! Honestly there is so much to talk about here in terms of gameplay, but I can promise you that this is peak survival horror from my experience (Resident Evil and Silent Hill respectively).[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]📜Story[/td]
        [td]The story is basic, simple, but actually really good. It’s a fun story that makes it so easy to understand and follow without getting lost. This is probably my favorite RE story since it’s the first that created the franchise, and it makes sense and can be somewhat believable. Reading all the files in the game really puts you in the experience and they are just so extremely fascinating to read and trying to imagine their situation they went through. Top tier storytelling in the files I must say! I won’t spoil the story, but it’s pretty predictable, but still a blast to play through.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🕛Playtime[/td]
        [td]With a healthy amount of unlocks and gamemodes, the replayability is high here. My first game took around 10 hours (that’s including checking every area and file). The game modes even bring more playtime which can change the game drastically, making it harder and a different experience. Each character has a different story as well (to a certain degree). Also you can install a randomizer mod that can really make the game feel challenging and can provide a unique playthrough, with each run being different and possible harder than the last (links will be below).[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🎧Sound[/td]
        [td]The sound design is perfect. All from the ambiance outside, hearing the crows and bugs in the night adds a calm, but eerie feeling. The zombie noises in each hallway, adding dread and fear to the experience. The sound track and safe room is absolutely incredible. The voice acting is better than the original, but still feels awkward in some areas.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]❗Bugs❗[/td]
        [td]There is one music score that is sped up for some reason. Not sure if it’s a bug, but if you heard the original than the remaster it’s noticeable. It’s not a huge deal if you haven’t played the original. There is a patch for this luckily which will be linked below. The game can crash if you ALT+TAB too many times as well.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🔅Performance[/td]
        [td]The game runs smoothly on my system. Having no frame drops or slowdowns. Besides the crashing issue, it’s pretty good! Just don’t ALT+TAB if possible since you will have a risk of crashing.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]✔️Pro’s[/td]
        [td][list]
[*]No cut content
[*]Good simple story
[*]Amazing lore
[*]Creepy ambiance[
[*]More locations added
[*]Incredible soundtrack
[*]Defense Items (added to the remake)
[*]Both characters have different pros/cons
[*]Unlockables (game modes, weapons, costumes)
[/list]
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]❌Con’s[/td]
        [td][list]
[*]Some backgrounds can look pretty rough
[*]Game can crash if ALT+Tab too many times
[/list]
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🏆Rating[/td]
        [td]10/10
This game is worth every penny! A gem of a game![/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🔗Conclusion[/td]
        [td]Resident Evil is a rare game to find not just on Steam, but in general. This was Resident Evil at its peak. I wish the RE2 and RE3 remakes followed this route but we still have the RE 1 Remake which is a gold staple of how you do a remake properly. This game made me enjoy Resident Evil as a whole and to this day, is still one of the best horror games to date. What can I say? It’s a gem of a game we all should play at least once in our life.[/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]
